|currently for ARM based codecs, we cant buffer more than one buffer as arm decoders are working on only two buffers.
if we try to buffer 2 at the v4l2 level, there will be a dead lock.
this will be changed once we move to ducati decoder completely.

|No. these are two different interfaces and the purpose is also entirely different.
Commit --&gt; This is used by surface flinger to update the overlay parameters upon every time the ONVISIBILITY is resolved by the window manager. it means every time when the window has to be resized or rotated or alpha to be chnaged etc.

ResizeInput --&gt; this is the interface for the Video MIO or the CameraHAL to destroy and re-create the overlay when the overlay size changes. like in H.263 decoder where the overlay size is not known in the beginning unless first frame is decoded. upon decoder callback the overlay is recreated with this resizeInput API.

Ideally InitializeOverlay and resizeInput are redundant and may be we can aim to unify them internally.
|fd can be ZERO.
i will add checks for -ve and OPEN_MAX bounds.

i will add checks for -ve and OPEN_MAX.
|two pipe lines are controlled by two overlay objects right.
and this mutex is overlay object specific, hence parallel posting is not hindered.

|Static: because we need to populate the function pointers for the surface flinger to access these, we have to make them static functions.

i have tested having two overlays simultaneously active from single process and from multiple processes.

|i am seeing a potential race condition possible here. may be we need mutex locking across the qd_buf_count variable.

the race condition: after the stream is enabled, but before returning the queued buffer count, if the commit happens and disables the stream, the queued count buffer count
would be reset to zero.
 and quebuffer api returns ZERO.
in this case CameraHAL behaves as if the buffer is queued after the stream off, but ideally not.
|potential race condition: if the queueBuffer call is pre-empted by commit and resets the buffer that just got queued.
im referring to the scenario where stream off is called, after
stream on but before returning from the queue buffer call.
refer to the dependent patch comments for more details of this scenario.

primary lcd, there is no change triggered at the commit api.
with the above background, inorder to meet the below usecase, this reset
is required:
(1) open overlay and request it for 2lcd
video should be played on secondary lcd
(2) destroy overlay and close the app

(3) open the overlay and request for lcd
video should be played on primary lcd.

|Initially we allowed resizeInput to be called even when the stream is ON, to support new camera mode switches in OMAP4. As part of that we added this scenario, so that if the call comes from camera HAL for the same size (between HS mode HQ mode switch) we can just flush the old buffers and return.
|this is the requirement from imaging team.
they wanted a mechanism to flush the buffers without destroying the overlay.

|Hi Naren,
There are two reasons for using explicit index:

(2) We need to define the same constant on Android Stagefright openmax header as well, where we dont want all the other custom indices, hence added a hardcoded index.

OMX_TI_STREAMINTERLACEFORMATTYPE: Implemented currently.

|Hi Saket,

This would cover only the messages received during the stop command execution and port flush execution. But what about the FBD/EBD received before the stop (before marking the ports as Shutting_Down.
|This is the tricky part, as i mentioned earlier, there are lot of scenarios we are hitting, and causing segfault. one of them is:

(1) Decoder is returning empty buffers without any error event
(2) OMXCodec is in STOP method, it changed the mstate = Executing_to_idle
and issued sendcommand to StateIdle
then waiting on a semaphore
(3) Then Decoder sent ERROR event, even before processing the stateChange Command.

(4) In this case the semaphore is signalled, since the component is in ERROR state, and completes the stop call even before component is moved to Idle.

(5) Then OMXCodec destructor comes, where FreeNode call thinks component is still in Execute state, so Initiate one more sendCommand to StateIdle.

(6) Here the SoftOMXComponent will segfault, because of redundant calls to same state transition.
|I agree with you, it is just a port Index difference.
|Yes, we hit this scenario in#
OMXCodec is in the execution of &quot;stop()&quot; method, it has issued the IdleState change, but it didn't wait till state transition is done, because of ERROR event.
Then it tries to free the Node, and comes here.

The Stop and free are happening so fast that even before OMX Component has executed the state change we are issuing two stateChange Commands.

this is happening for some clips.
|I don't think so.
I have considered a scenario, where Client (OMXCodec.cpp) didn't send any Idle state transition, meaning when there is no redundant commands.
this is only a safe side loop to make sure on going transitions are done.
But we can't assume any state at the end of the loop.
It could be either Executing or Idle.
|Hi Illia,

I fully agree with your comment. In that scenario, it guarantees that COMPONENT really went into badstate, as it failed to finish the transition in 1sec.

Hence it maybe ok to generate segfault and recover.

|I have just one query#
This is not a spec requirement, right.

if the source and sink are at different native resolutions, earlier we were sending source native resolution and sink used to do scaling, now we are scaling on the source side itself.

My suggestion is.. instead of hardcoding whether to respect sink or source native resolution, we can see which native resolution is the best to reduce the network payload.
eg: if (source_native_resolution &gt; sink_native_resolution)
         best_vid_mode = sink_native_resolution
//so that we downscale first and then send out on n/w
 else
         bast_mode = source_native_resolution
//so that the upscale happens on the sink side

|Buftype carries the handle type, whether it is a virtual pointer, gralloc handle, or ion handle. Here, the conversion is done from:

dest: gralloc pointer for buffer of NV-12
|we can avoid this call if the crop is already at the requested value, by checking the requested param vs the src/dest queue params.
|(1) Codec returns outputID in sequential array starting from &quot;0&quot; index. Once we hit NULL outputID, that is the end of the valid data from Codec.

(2) Im initializing the variable &quot;i&quot; to &quot;0&quot; at line # 311
So i parse the entire freeID array and process all the buffers that codec freed in that process call.
|The original idea when we added flags to memplugin_alloc was to carry any flag (eg cacheable, and caching types etc). 

Lets leave it as flags to be generic and inline with memplugin_alloc().
|Android OMX components use memplugin interface for all allocs.
Please add separate function for dsp_memplugin_allo.
|The issue popped out only because we have 3 pipes instead of 4.  It used to work earlier because we had 4 pipes, and all math results in &quot;ints&quot;. but now with max of 3 dss pipes.

this is the logic on HWC side:
#ifdef EARLYCAMERA_IPU
#define MAX_DSS_OVERLAYS 3
#else
#define MAX_DSS_OVERLAYS 4
#endif

thats why im using MAX_DSS_OVERLAYS constant here which will guarantee the max overlays available for HWC.
|since dei_regs is a a static struct, may be we dont need to check it everytime. but im wondering may be we should check for the ctx, parameter to this method, if it was not checked in the calling method.
|are we sure that this method is not expected to be called from other files and modules?
|i think we should init them to '1'.
|dont comment this line. it was just a WA on your setup
|remove extra space
|lets define something like max number of gpios and parse only till that number. so that we dont parse unwanted gpios on J6EVM and fail the driver.
|we still have tiler and dmm drivers. Dont we need this chmod?
|Are we sure we dont need tiler driver access here?
is ION driver hiding everything inside?
|we cleaned-up the DOMX the dependency.
and there is no omap4xxx/domx folder.
|We should change the max simultaneous cameras as well.
|one suggestion: Instead of adding these checks everywhere inside libdce, it will be good if you could abstract it inside the libdce client (some TI HAL component for GLSDK) and then use memHeader's offset field to pass the UV buffer offset. This is what i Implemented in Android and im reusing this offset for even decoder input buffer offsets. I remember you telling that there is no TI MMHAL for GLSDK, if it is still the case, we have to live with these checks here anyway.
|I dont see license headers for any make files.
|since it is inside dra7xx folder, do we still need to check for variants?? today we have only J6 and J6eco, and this is applicable for both.
|Earlier we used to keep all the changes under OMAP_ENHANCEMENT check, is it no longer required????
|Do we need these changes???
|why is this zlib required??
|These changes are legacy from omap4. we dont need them here.
|This logic should go into else part of sw vsync. otherwise we end of having this thread created even for SW Vsync scenarios.
|Does it work for QNX???
|Where are we disabling the planes unused in this composition but were previously enabled.
|Why are we excluding &quot;0&quot;th layer?
|Do we really need this dss_plane_limit variable?
I think we can achieve the same with the variable &quot;avail_ovls&quot;
|do you want to keep these logs to enable in future for debugging purpose??
|This limitation should be removed once we have DSS acceleration patches merged.
|I guess you are checking it inside bdev-&gt;prepare(), right.
Still you may have to check for layer not being NULL before accessing its composition type here.
|there is a possibility of getting some NULL layers, or layers with SKIP flag. We should check for them.
|I think we should check for layer for not NULL before accessing its compostionType. I remember having a scenario where some of the  layers could be NULL.
|my previous comment for removing dead code for logs is applicable everywhere.
|Change this hardcoding. Use the below formula:
width = ALIGN(width, HW_ALIGN)

include hal_public.h to get the ALIGN macro and HW_ALIGN definitions.
|Why do we need two buffers? is it for Y and UV planes??
we can allocate only one buffer and pass offset for the second plane.
|I thought of adding the suggestion of duplicating the pointer on Y and UV desc as part of my first review comment, but refrained thinking that codec might be checking for pointer on Y and UV planes not being the same!
If they require two different pointers, we can still provide them with two pointers on single memplugin allocated buffers.
|Do we want to close the rpmsg-dce device when the buffers are destroyed? and re-create during the next first buffer creation??
it may result into multiple times open and close for rpmsg-dce device. Lets run our robustness tests with this patch before merging.
|This count will be finalized after testing with the optimized TILER-1D patches
|OSAL_ErrorTrace is not functional, hence thought of changing the error traces to ALOGE.
|Will address it.
|How about the above DeleteTask call. The same deadlock can happen here as well, right?
Probably we need to move the mutex acquire further down!!

Also, we may need to check which of these call need to be protected from being re-entrant, so that we can place mutex acquire accordingly.

|Patch Set 1:

yes i understand.
but the point what i would like to emphasize here is:
(1) as per the power management guidelines, we should not enable the HW unless it is requested for use. and we should disable it once done. 
  but here in this logic, the display1 is always enabled.
(2) going forward, the managers and the overlay devices are not statically mapped, hence we need to have a logic to query and then set the device to appropriate manager.

  so i prefer we should have this piece of code in our surface flinger or somewhere else, instead of init.rc.

Hi Grigory,

there are 2 concerns:
(1) Why did you add setParameter to the control context interface. this is accessible only by the surface flinger.
I assume that, this setparameter is expected to be called by the client once it detects 3D content, right? Please correct me if im wrong.

(2) The current overlay library is common between OMAP3 and OMAP4. Since S3D is applicable only for OMAP4, please guard all S3D calls under TARGET_OMAP4 macro.

|Patch Set 1:

Hi Hari,

If i understand O_NONBLOCK functionality correctly, none of the functions with this file descriptor cause the calling process to Wait. Hence, there is no looping at all with this patch. (there was always looping in the earlier logic).

But the actual concern would be in the normal working scenario where: previously the DQUE call guaranteed to return the free buffer, and this assumption is no longer valid in the subsequent logic. For this we can look at Lajo's suggestion of implementing timer.
|Patch Set 1:

Muthu,

I have implemented timer based approach as per Lajo's suggestion. but do you mean there are no patches required from overlay at all for this suspend-resume??

|Patch Set 1:

Hi Kalpesh,

There is no specific reason on why it can't be added in device open. But my idea is to defer the data structure population till the overlay data object is successfully created.
If your next question is: then why is it added in device open for control object !!!
then my answer is device open for control object is one time, where as overlay create is for every overlay object we create.

|Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve


|Patch Set 1:

Muthu,

You are absolutely right.
The issue is not with KEY_S3D_SUPPORTED.
The fault is due to &quot; KEY_S3D2D_PREVIEW&quot;

the actual fix is to check for non-NULL for this param.
and the same logic is added for KEY_S3D_SUPPORTED as it could be next potential issue on customer platforms where the xml is entirely different from TIs.
|Patch Set 1:

That is one of the options.
But the argument there would be: if we start adding all the parameters to all the sensors, then every new camera property xml file has to carry all the irrelevant values.

|Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve


|Patch Set 1:

Hi Keith,

Yes, HDMI kernel driver is sending some spurious events during cable attach (due to debouncing may be).
I'm cheking with kernel team for this. But in any case,
I feel it is good to have some kind of stablizing timer even on user side. Thats why submitted this patch.
|Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Kalpesh,
The new debounce timer doesn't add any delay for the actual events, because we start timer and go ahead with servicing the event.
The delay comes into picture for the subsequent spurious events with will happen within 1sec. I chose 1 sec because no human activated events can happen within 1 sec, right.
|Patch Set 1:

Kalpesh,

In the sequence of spurious events, the first one should always be the correct one, otherwise, if it is the same as the current state, there wouldn't be any event, right?

Eg: we are at State0

Trigger: Cable attached
state1
state0 
state1
.
.
.
is the only sequence possible. It cant be 
state0
state1
state0
.
.
because, in the second scenario,there would not any event for state0-&gt; state0

|Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

|Patch Set 1:

Hi Keith,

It is the hdmi observer from VideoView which is getting destroyed.
My understanding is that, earlier we are calling new for every videoview construction, but it is not freed explicitly (might be getting freed in the background by garbage collector).
But now with this patch we are freeing it up more explicitly.
|Patch Set 1:

Hi Keith,

What do you mean by initial HDMI state??
is it the state when we instantiate Video view??
if so, as soon as Video View registers with hdmi observer, the current state (which is the initial state wrt to Videoview) is notified to it.

|Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Hi Keith,

In order to enhance usecases and support some optimizations for playback, there is a need to pass few parameters during overlay creation itself. We can't use setParameter as the decision needs to be taken during overlay creation itself.
eg: to set the overlay number of buffers, to set Video modes like low power or clone and if any in future.

|Uploaded patch set 2.
|Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Thanks Anu. I have added OMAP4 checks.
|Patch Set 2:

Hi Keith,

zorder is a DSS HW feature by which we can control the ordering of the video &amp; graphics pipelines on the DSS overlay managers.
eg: we can specify whether GFX pipeline is on top or bottom of video pipeline through this zorder value. Here z refers to the (z axis in 3D plane).
The corresponding kernel patch is
http://review.omapzoom.org/#change,10675
|Patch Set 2:

This is a new feature in OMAP4, and not supported on OMAP3.
|Patch Set 2:

Hi Keith,

For Froyo, L25x is still on 2.6.32 kernel i believe.
Hence the branches are entirely different.
When we move to GB where OMAP3 will also be on 2.6.35 we needn't have omap4 check in bionic.
|Patch Set 2:

Hi Keith,

Sorry i didn't get your comment.
My idea is to not to break any other version of V4L2. Hence i added omap4 check in bionic. This new parameter will come into picture only for OMAP4 platform, in which case our kernel patch handles this new parameter.
|Patch Set 2:

Hi Hari/Keith,

I agree with your point that it can be ignored for omap3 if it not configurable in the hardware.
The problem comes wrt to header while compiling the dependent libraries. If i add it in bionic without processor checks,
I need to add this parameter even in 2.6.32 kernel code base
If you have any suggestions on handling this in a better way, i'm ready to incorporate them.
|Patch Set 2:

Hi Keith,

Please let me know if i answered your comments.
This patch has to be merged soon as the kernel patch has already gone in.
|Patch Set 2:

Hi Keith,

This is one of the options i proposed above.
but i have implemented the second option of having processor check so that i neednt touch omap3 code base.

|Patch Set 1:

Hi Kalpesh,

This is not a issue with Z-order or Color key.
Because we enabled per-pixel alpha ideally if the framebuffer was 1080p, surface flinger would have allocated proper window and the alpha blend would have been enabled properly in the UI buffer.But currently we are upscaling the WVGA, this issue comes.
But we can workaround by z-order or colorkey.
|Uploaded patch set 2.
|Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve


|Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve


|Patch Set 1:

|Uploaded patch set 2.
|Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

removed omap_enahcement macro.
|Patch Set 2:

Hi Saket,

Mirroring is enabled intentionally for secondary camera.
But this patch is clashing with overlay rotation patch and hence mirror is halfway done, this is because the rotation is disabled for HDMI. I will fix the liboverlay patch and then we can submit both together.
|Patch Set 2:

Because the secondary camera is a front facing camera.
Whatever it captures would be mirror image of ours.
In order get proper preview we need to do horizontal mirroring.
Where as for primary camera, which is back facing one, captures normal image.
|Patch Set 2:

Hi Kalpesh,

I have already answered this. Here is the summary of my answers:
(1) Mirroring is broken on HDMI because of liboverlay rotation fix. this is why you are seeing vertically flipped image on HDMI. This one i have fixed in liboverlay patch.

(2) without mirroring for front facing camera, if you observe preview carefully, you will see the below issue:
  If you raise your right hand infront of camera, you will see as if left hand is raised. you can do that experiment to understand this feature.

And Android has enabled this mirroring from Camera service in GB. it is not what we are doing from APP.
Our responsibility is to service the flip call from surface flinger. This is what i had provided sometime back.
|Patch Set 2:

Please use the patchset2 of
http://review.omapzoom.org/#change,11420

to fix secondary camera mirror issue on HDMI.
|Patch Set 2:

Hi Jean,

Kalpesh's comments are addressed in 


http://review.omapzoom.org/#change,11464  -- Merged 

Hence this patch can go in now.

|Patch Set 1:

The changes look fine:
but we need to hold till overlay solution is finalized.
Currently we dont enable color key with graphics destination.

HDMI+ rotation+ then only enable this destination color key.
|Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this


|Patch Set 1:

Kalpesh,

till now we are using only video source transparency for enabling color key. Now for the first time we are going to enable gfx-destination,:
And i need more undetstanding of kernel for this.
Hence taking time.
|Patch Set 1:

I see another issue with Vid1 zorder being 0:

currently in overlay we limit the vid pipe zorder being 0 or 1.
So, if the app sets zorder to 0, the behavior would become unpredictable in H/W.
If i hardcode the zorder, there is no more control from app!
|Patch Set 1:

The issue is because of two video pipes having the same zorder.

H/W behvior is unpredictable in that scenario. that is the probelm.
|Patch Set 1:

So in my overlay patch: 
I'm changing the zorder only for TV case.
This is with the assumption that we support UI cloning only on TV. hope this is a valid assumption.

|Patch Set 1:

Saket,

This is a port from Froyo.
It was missed our during syncup activity.

Here is the corresponding Froyo patch.
http://review.omapzoom.org/#change,6505
|Patch Set 1:

We will need this logic to eliminate the multiple seek events coming from Media Player with in few milli secs.
This results in seeking to the same IFrame and hence results in repeating Video and Audio.
But the threshold needs to be identified and also the location for this buffering logic, If media player is not acceptable, it should be done in application at least.
|Patch Set 1:

Karim has ported the Music player logic to Media controller to handle the multiple seek events. We will verify Yong's patch and that one, and we can decide which is more robust,
We can reuse this patch for music player port to have history.
|Uploaded patch set 2.
|Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

This one is fixing the jitter during AV clip seek.
This is the same logic as used in Android Music Player app to avoid bounce during Audio seek.
|Patch Set 2:

Hi Saket,

I fully agree with your comment.
In fact yesterday myself and Ajay were thinking the same thing. But we cant find out the next Iframe duration at Media Controller level and one more thing is if the repetion of video if of the order of seconds (because of I frames are seconds apart) we dont see jitter instead it will be clear from video that it got adjusted to the nearest I frame. But for small durations like msec repetition is manifesting like a jitter.
|Patch Set 2:

Saket,

It seems the 250msec used for music player is not related to Audio buffer, instead it is like user capability to issue two seeks within 250 msec. In any human interaction events, two event can not be triggered within 250msec, with that confidence, i believe the debouncing time is arrived at for music player.

Incorporated review comments.
|Patch Set 2:

I think the default timings of the driver are not zero.
It is VGA, which means that till HDMI is first attached we are anyway maintaining non ZERO value.
And here the issue is not in delaying the event to user.
As mentioned in the description, after delay of 100msec, once the event is communicated to user, the timings are reset to zero because of detach event.
|Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve


|Uploaded patch set 2.

|Uploaded patch set 3.
|Patch Set 3: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

incorporated review comments.
|Patch Set 3:

Hi Saket,

This can't be handled on user side.
Because if streamON fails, user side state machine would never call streamOff, instead it tries to call streamON
once again for the next buffer.
This would result in deadlock.

|Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hi Srinidhi,

I think the check is intentionally not done here, because S3D V4L2 doesn't implement this custom IOCTL hence this call would always fail for them.
If we add this patch, it will break all S3D usecases.
|Patch Set 1:

Hi Nidhi,

Returning error from Overlay doesn't solve the issue.
On overlay creation failure, AwesomePlayer falls back to Software Renderer and will result in segmentation fault.
Hence the solution would be to return from parser itself.

|Patch Set 1:

Saket,

The logic to handle 1/4 and 8 scaling factors are already taken care in the earlier patches.
Now this patch is to avoid any scaling (not even 1/2) while rendering at 1080p timings.
This is the limitation with DSS pipe line scaling while rendering to 1080p TV.
I have nackd it because crop i intended for TV is effecting LCD.

|Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

The description of the patch says there are errors because DISPC is accessing stale registers on resume.

This is not Correct, DISPC is already taking care of disabling all the VID pipes on suspend, hence on resume DISPC doesn't access any buffers unless they are explicitly enabled by user side after providing the valid buffer pointers,

And the change in the patch is incorrect as we are enabling the pipe without making sure that there are valid buffers queued before enabling it.

(1 inline comment)

Hi Saket/Artem,

My answers are inline.
And i didn't get why do you say it is a hack.
It is the kernel recommended synchronization method to guarantee that no IRQ handlers are executed after this call on any CPU. That is what we exactly want here.

Please let me know your options.

|Patch Set 1:

Hi Artem,

I have tested both the scenarios, and didn't observe any issue.
(1) Wifi signal strength: The patch doesn't come into picture when there is no video, hence this scenario is uneffected

(2) Youtube app: We support only full screen mode on TV when Video is present, no more cloning.
Hence there is no concept of entering and exiting full screen mode on HDMI. 
HDMI is always showing the full screen and LCD is entering and exiting full screen properly.
|Patch Set 1:

Hi Jean,

I have verified both the scenarios he mentioned,and didn't see any issue.
Please go ahead with the merge.

Since for Tablets, the activity is destroyed and recreated during rotation, it will follow the same path as starting the playback. Hence all the controls are brought to visibility on rotation.

|Patch Set 1:

(6 comments)
|Patch Set 1:

Hi Saurabh,

(1) Your assumption for single client &lt;-&gt; single process is not valid in Android. I think it wouldn't be valid even in Linux/QNX once they verify at complete UI level. Today you see multiprocess behavior because of test case.

(2) If there are no two clients in the single process, then there is no value add by the semaphore logic earlier. since it was created new for every client. 

(3) The reason i moved the count check outside the dce_ipc_init is to reuse the single count check between sem and ipc handle creates.
|Patch Set 1:

Hi Buddy/Pradeep/saurabh,

Please refer to the below patch and lets continue our discussion there:

http://review.omapzoom.org/#/c/33853/

|Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.
|Patch Set 1:

Hi Pradeep,

In which usecase are you facing this issue?
I have seen the same packet corruption issue during simultaneous encode and decode, where in, the process and control calls are preempted or executed in parallel. And i have pushed a similar patch but only to protect control and process calls.
http://review.omapzoom.org/#/c/34475/

And would like to get confirmation from IPC team that the packet corruption is indeed an expected behavior if multiple clients issue requests simultaneously.

Can we move the lock to just around MmRpc_call()?
|Patch Set 1: Verified+1 Code-Review+1

This patch breaks LI (OV10633) sensor.
The VIN2_S2 and VIN2_S0 GPIOs are common b/w LI and TVP sensor controls and hence need to be set in their probes.

|Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Hi Marcus,

We need to check why HDMI is detected and published as the first display when no HDTV is connected.

There is no assumption from Android UI or HWC for display ordering. It relies on Kernel for deciding the display order, and whatever is decided as the the first display (display0) that is what is configured and controlled from HWC init_primary display.
|Patch Set 1:

Hi Marcus,

and so, you can remove the setState from here.

|Dont return NULL. it will be interpreted as OK.
|Sundar, I considered your proposal. But it is clashing with the slice mode implementation. We cannot have camera going to idle first. Tunnel must be setup first, and then encoder goes to idle and then only camera can move to idle.
|This change will trigger the query for [max_camera - starting_camera] times. That is not what we want.. We want to query only once  only for that particular camera id.
In other words, we want the while loop in CameraAdapter_Capabilities() to execute only once. 

So, please try this out:

Int discard_this_parameter;
CameraAdapter_Capabilities(properties, X, X+1, &amp;discard_this_parameter)

Do not use num_cameras for the last parameter. It will be overwritten with incorrect value. It may create a bug in future.
|Please remove these 2 comment lines.
After submitting the patch. Add them as review comments so that people reviewing the patch will understand.
|I am not sure about this change Shouldnt it be like this..

switchToState(){

        const OMX_ERRORTYPE switchError = OMX_SendCommand(mComponent,
                OMX_CommandStateSet, mState, 0);
        CAMHAL_LOGD(&quot;Switching to state 0x%x... DONE&quot;, mState);

        if ( switchError != OMX_ErrorNone )
        {
	If (switchError == OMX_ErrorInsufficientResources)
		Return SOME_UNIQUE_ERROR; // to indicate that the camera is in use
	Else return ErrorUtils::omxToAndroidError(switchError);
        }

}

fetchCapabilitiesForSensor(){
.

        const OMX_ERRORTYPE sensorSelectError = OMX_SetConfig(component(),
                (OMX_INDEXTYPE)OMX_TI_IndexConfigSensorSelect, &amp;sensorSelect);
        CAMHAL_LOGD(&quot;Selecting sensor %d... DONE&quot;, sensorId);

        if ( sensorSelectError != OMX_ErrorNone )
        {
            CAMHAL_LOGD(&quot;Max supported sensor number reached: %d&quot;, sensorId);
            return MAX_SENSOR_REACHED;
        }
.
        const status_t idleSwitchError = switchToState(OMX_StateIdle);
        if ( idleSwitchError != NO_ERROR )
        {
            CAMHAL_LOGE(&quot;Failed to switch to Idle state, error: %d&quot;, idleSwitchError);
            return idleSwitchError;
        }
.
}

CameraAdapter_Capabilities(){

While(){

If (err == MAX_SENSOR_REACHED)
	Break;

If ((err != NO_ERROR) &amp;&amp; (err != SOME_UNIQUE_ERROR) {
	eError = OMX_ErrorHardware;
	Break;
}
}

}
|Some applications dont check the number of cameras first.
For example, the current android camera app does not perform this check.
|Response for getNumberOfCameras()
---------------------
if that is so, then i need to add the above logic to getNumberOfCameras() as well. 2 things can happen

1. The app queries while VTC is in progress. In which case, even if i query the camera module once again, it will still return 0 and therefore the app will not call connect.

2. The app queries after VTC has been stopped. In which case, we query the camera module and it returns the right number of cameras and the app continues and calls connect.

int32_t CameraService::getNumberOfCameras() {
    if (mNumberOfCameras == 0) mNumberOfCameras = mModule-&gt;get_number_of_cameras();
    return mNumberOfCameras;
}

---------------------
Response for getCameraInfo()
---------------------
The query is rerouted to CameraHal_Module which will take care to read again from ducati if the information was not previously populated. So no chnages needed here.

--------------

|Once startPreview is called, there is no need to continue to remember whether the function cameraPreviewInitialization() was called earlier or not. And so the flag mPreviewInitializationDone is reset here. Plus, this preserves the current behavior of startPreview under the circumstances where the application calls startPreview twice or more.
|stopPreview() will be called explicitly by the application.
Remember that we want the stopPreview to happen in 2 steps. When CAMERA_CMD_PREVIEW_DEINITIALIZATION is called, the component moves to idle state and when stopPreview is called, the component moves to loaded state.
|agreed.
|agreed
|not sure i completely understand.. will do my best.
|Yes. That's correct. I had added 3 commands initially:
    1. set up tunnel
    2. camera preview init
    3. destroy tunnel

---------------------------

And after a few email exchanges with sundar, it was decided to change it this way:

     1. set up tunnel - make it a setParameter

     2. camera preview init - stayed as is
     3. destroy tunnel - renamed as camera preview deinit since setup tunnel was removed.
|Well...  that was the original implementation. But since you asked me to remove changes to framework, i had to resort to this..
|ok
|i could.. But it is not necessary since the same instance of CameraHal is not going to be used for non VTC purposes. But for future proofing, i will reset it here.
|Everywhere - meaning in decoder and encoder - OMX_COLOR_FormatYUV420PackedSemiPlanar is the format we use... i found it odd that camera uses OMX_COLOR_FormatYUV420SemiPlanar...

Anyway, for both formats, the result is the same.. i didnt find difference in camera output.

For uniformity's sake, i set it to OMX_COLOR_FormatYUV420PackedSemiPlanar
|Disabling the preview port and freeing the buffers caused ducati to go into a bad state.This issue is observed only during slice mode. Therefore, preview port disable/enable has been removed and the preview buffers are now freed when moving from idle to loaded state. 

This issue is known to ducati folks and they recommended this approach. 

Since we are freeing the buffers when moving from idle to loaded state, port disable is not needed anymore. Since there is no port disable, port enable is not required either.
|Disabling the preview port and freeing the buffers caused ducati to go into a bad state.This issue is observed only during slice mode. Therefore, preview port disable/enable has been removed and the preview buffers are now freed when moving from idle to loaded state. 

This issue is known to ducati folks and they recommended this approach. 

Since we are freeing the buffers when moving from idle to loaded state, port disable is not needed anymore. Since there is no port disable, port enable is not required either.

|Patch Set 1: Abandoned
|Patch Set 1: No score; No score

I had to revert several patches because otherwise the PV patch does not apply cleanly.

Even with this patch, audio and video goes out of sync when you do FF or REW in a fast manner. That is, if you press the FF/REW button 2 times really quick, then the sync is lost. But it is due to an issue with the getPosition API. After a FF/REW, the getPosition API must restart from 0. But it does not reset sometimes. This causes the clock correction logic to misbehave. I can explain further to whomever will be working on the Audio Flinger.

Although this patch does not fix all AV Sync issue, I still think we need to take it, because it fixes some of the bugs in the previous PV patches. James quoted &quot;Last patch had a bug where the newly created thread would spin and this would slow down the entire phone.&quot; Refer to https://pvjira.pv.com/browse/TIANDROID-40 for more information.

I have tested for non-720p clips. i did not notice any regression. Sorry, I didnt have time to test 720P.

|Patch Set 1: No score; I would prefer that you didn't submit this


|Patch Set 1:

Your patch sparked an idea. We could do it this way:

The goal is to keep at least 2 buffers in the overlay at all times. It is ok to enable streaming after queueing just one buffer.

Replace buf_count with frame_count to make it more meaningful.

Initialize frame_count in createOverlay() and in disable_streaming().

Increment frame_count in overlay_queueBuffer() after the buffer has been successfully queued.

In overlay_queueBuffer() replace this 'if' condition 

if ( ctx-&gt;shared-&gt;qd_buf_count &gt;= NUM_BUFFERS_TO_BE_QUEUED_FOR_OPTIMAL_PERFORMANCE &amp;&amp;  
   (ctx-&gt;shared-&gt;streamEn == 0))

with 

if ( ctx-&gt;shared-&gt;streamEn == 0)


In overlay_dequeueBuffer(), replace this 'if' condition

if ( ctx-&gt;shared-&gt;qd_buf_count &lt;= 1 )

with

if ( ( ctx-&gt;shared-&gt;qd_buf_count &lt;= 1 ) &#124;&#124; (ctx-&gt;shared-&gt;frame_count &lt; NUM_BUFFERS_TO_BE_QUEUED_FOR_OPTIMAL_PERFORMANCE))

Note that qd_buf_count and frame_count server different purposes. qd_buf_count keeps track how many buffers are in the display driver at any time. frame_count keeps track of how many buffers were queued to the display driver after STREAM _ON. frame_count is never decremented.
|Patch Set 1:

please resolve this issue. lingering for too long.

i agree it is trivial..

Keith,

|Uploaded patch set 2.
|Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I read this in the ndk documentation:

  III.2. Android Platform ABI support:
  ------------------------------------
    The Android system knows at runtime which ABI(s) it supports. More precisely, up to two build-specific system properties are used to indicate:
    - the 'primary' ABI for the device, corresponding to the machine code used in the system image itself.
    - an optional 'secondary' ABI, corresponding to another ABI that is also supported by the system image.
    For example, a typical ARMv5TE-based device would only define
    the primary ABI as 'armeabi' and not define a secondary one.
    On the other hand, a typical ARMv7-based device would define the primary ABI to 'armeabi-v7a' and the secondary one to 'armeabi'
    since it can run application native binaries generated for both
    of them. 

So should I do this instead:
TARGET_CPU_ABI := armeabi armeabi-v7a
or this... (dont know the right way yet)
TARGET_CPU_ABI := armeabi-v7a
TARGET_CPU_ABI2 := armeabi

I see the package manager using this...

    public static final String CPU_ABI = getString(&quot;ro.product.cpu.abi&quot;);

    /** The name of the second instruction set (CPU type + ABI convention) of native code. */
    public static final String CPU_ABI2 = getString(&quot;ro.product.cpu.abi2&quot;);

|Patch Set 3: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Added the omapenhancement flag.
|Patch Set 3:

Keith,

This bug was discovered when integrating overlay in flash playback. The buffer pointers were passed across process boundaries. Flash and OMX execute in different processes. Because the offset was not passed, all buffers were being mapped to the same physical address. So, even though the virtual address was different for each buffer, they all mapped to the same physical address.
|Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

|Uploaded patch set 3.

|Patch Set 4: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve


|Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Keith,

In general, I agree with your comments.
However, in this particular scenario, it is not a codec issue. Here's why:

Sometimes, clips may have a few bad frames in the middle and our codec is capable of recognizing the bad frames and ignoring them - with the hope that subsequent frames will be good and that we can continue decoding.

With this particular clip, there are no good frames after a certain point, so, codec returns all the input buffers without decoding them. Therefore, there is no valid output buffer to return either. Therefore, OMXCodec hangs indefitely waiting for a buffer. That is what i am correcting with this patch.

Anu
|Patch Set 5:

OMXCodec is just waiting for an output buffer to become available. Ducati does not have one to provide since the input is junk. Ducati does not report an error because this could be a temporary condition and we may recover from it.
|Patch Set 5:

https://review.source.android.com/#change,22353


2. I have started a conversation with Ducati team on alternate solutions. I have looped you in on it.

3. I verified with Yong that in the case of streaming, AwesomePlayer pauses the whole state machine when it is starved of input. So, this logic will not come into play in that situation.

|Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

During normal playback, you should not be hitting this condition at all.

|Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve


|Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve


|Uploaded patch set 2.
|Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Here are the answers to comments posted on Patch 1:

&gt;&gt;&gt;virtual ~BufferAllocator() {} 
&gt;&gt;&gt;why is this virtual?
Answer: 
http://www.codersource.net/c/c-miscellaneous/c-virtual-destructors.aspx
http://blogs.msdn.com/b/oldnewthing/archive/2004/05/07/127826.aspx

&gt;&gt;&gt; error handling for allocateOutputBuffers() not implemented
Answer: Error handling is not required. If we fail to allocate buffers from v4l2-gfx driver, then we simply continue to request ducati to allocate the buffers  Meaning if allocateOutputBuffers() fails, then we fall back to the old design. In a way, error handling is done by setting the right flags within allocateOutputBuffers().

&gt;&gt;&gt;if (!mBufferAllocator) return UNKNOWN_ERROR;
&gt;&gt;&gt;close mLibHandle before return error?
Answer: it is not necessary since it is taken care of within freeOutputBuffers(). But I incorporated it anyway.

&gt;&gt;&gt;if (mBufferAllocator)  delete mBufferAllocator;
&gt;&gt;&gt;curious which mem to free for this &quot;delete&quot;?
Answer: Verified that the derived class destructor is called.

&gt;&gt;&gt; may be a quirk should be used for this
Answer: I cannot use a quirk since I do not know when a flash usecase is being executed vs some other usecase. I asked Adobe to set some flag in the meta data so that we know when a flash usecase is executed, but they refused to put it in for the moment. That change will go in 2 months later..
|Patch Set 2:

FYI:
Today, flash performance is at 30 fps for WVGA. Our ultimate goal is to be at 30 fps for 1080P. We cannot get there is one big jump because of the many dependencies between adobe/TI/Google. But we still have to makes some improvements for customers going to production in the next few months. As a first step, we are attempting 720p @ 30 fps.

To attain 720p@30 fps, we need this patch.
To achieve 1080p@30 fps, we are going to build on top of this patch (using GFX driver).

Old logic on output buffer allocation:

Gallery use case: 2D Buffers were allocated by TIHardwareRenderer/DSS and passed to OMXCodec. OMXCodec called UseBuffer.

Non Gallery use cases: 1D Buffers were allocated by ducati and passed to OMXCodec. OMXCodec called AllocateBuffer.

New logic on output buffer allocation:

Gallery use case: 2D Buffers were allocated by TIHardwareRenderer/DSS and passed to OMXCodec. OMXCodec called UseBuffer.

Non Gallery use cases: 2D Buffers are allocated by GFX and passed to OMXCodec. OMXCodec called UseBuffer. if buffer allocation by GFX failed, then same as before.
|Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

will abandon soon
|Patch Set 2: Abandoned
|Uploaded patch set 2.
|Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Saket,

For the moment, we are only using the buffers allocated by the V4L2 GFX driver. So, not much to explain here.

Later on, in the case of flash, all post processing(scaling, dither, etc) will be done by the SGX. That use case mandates that we use the V4L2 gfx driver and the other APIs listed here. Currently, there is too much confusion as to what approach and in what time frame it will be done..
|Uploaded patch set 3.
|Uploaded patch set 4.
|Patch Set 4: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve


|Patch Set 4:

I first investigated the Tiler Mem Mngr to see if i can allocate 2D buffers for NV12. Unfortunately, it does not have right APIs for this purpose. Using the current Tiler MemMngr APIs, i will get 2 pointers - one for y and one for uv - since y is 8 bits and uv is 16 bits.
Plus, i will not have all the information (eg: fd) for creating the IMemory pointers for those addresses.

Looks like the dss and gfx drivers perform some trick to get a single pointer for y and uv such that uv is contigous to Y.

Another reason for using gfx is that - in future - we plan to use the SGX for performing certain post processing functions. In that case, it is necessary to allocate buffers using the gfx driver.

These patches are only the first step towards achieving 1080p 30 fps.

will abandon soon

|Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve


|Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Tested flash.
Tested gallery playback.
Tested thumbnail generation of clips requiring port reconfig.

This patch replaces all my previous patches on eliminating memcopy.

We are going this route bcos:

1. Change in strategy from Adobe. No GPU build for GB.
2. Giving 2D buffers to upper layers means they need to be careful how they touch the buffer. a simple memcpy will cause faults!
3. 1D appears to be giving better performance..

|Patch Set 1:

Saket,

At the moment, there is no intention to submit this patch to Google. There are multiple customers developing VTC solution with differing architecture. It is not clear yet what kind of changes [if any] are required in frameworks to support them. In the meantime, we developed our own test app to test simultaneous playback + record and other vtc specific features. This test app is helping us uncover issues not usually seen with Gallery Playback / UI Camera. Plus, since we are trying to steer our customers to use stagefright as much as possible, our application was written to use stagefright. 

For these reasons, I am not comfortable talking to James about this, yet. And, we could like these patches merged so that we can add our test app to the DB testing so as to uncover breaks in functionality as soon as possible.

Anu

This is reverting the build back to the previous version of ALSA and then breaking the build of FM Radio:

 mytime -o afs.out make -j2  2&gt;&amp;1 &#124;tee afs.out      build/core/product_config.mk:261: WARNING: adding test OTA key
============================================
TARGET_PRODUCT=zoom2
TARGET_BUILD_VARIANT=eng

A DR tells me that someone cared about there being a link from lib to /system/lib  at least enough to file a DR on it.  So, there is at least 1 reason to not have it.  Seems to me the proper solution here is to remove the hard coded paths from the BT code.  That improves the BT code for the future and allows it to work with Android.

Luis,

796 is essentially Anu merging 788 which has already been merged to the tree.  When you see &quot;merged&quot; patches, they are usually when the developer has manually pulled a patch and then submitted their new code.  I don't know the correct way to do this but essentially they are resubmitting the patch that they pulled down.

The one this one is dependent on has already been merged so you will have no net affect from this.

Jean

|Okay, I think I see what is going on.  This is patch set 2 for 1551 which was done on eclair rather than donut.  

Here's how I'd fix it.  

1) pull down the 1551 code in eclair.
2) create a separate donut repository.  
3) Compare the files in the two directories using something like BeyondCompare and ensure you aren't going to overwrite anything with your changes.  The result of this will create &quot;merged&quot; files.
4) Copy the &quot;merged&quot; files to donut.  
5) Create a new patch with these files.
6) Abandon this change and 1551 listing the new patch number.

This patch needs reviewers.
|Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

We need to isolate our changes in Google areas, specifically in frameworks base. Here is the new requirement based on customer feedback: 

Each of the patches needs to be revisited (commit list attached). If it just added functionality  then all is needed is some #ifdef added. If it replaced, deleted, or modified the code  then the original code needs to be put back and the TI code #ifdef. I dont need a meeting for that. 



We will use the define  OMAP_ENHANCEMENT. So the code would look like 

#ifdef OMAP_ENHANCEMENT 

&lt;some nice ti change&gt; 

#else 

&lt;previous Android (assuming the change modified the original code) 

#endif 



Android.mk files in affected areas will need to have the following in it 

Ifneq (,$(findstring omap, $(TARGET_BOARD_PLATFORM))) 

LOCAL_CFLAGS += -DOMAP_ENCHANCEMENT 

endif 


Please rework as appropriate.

We need to isolate our changes in Google areas, specifically in frameworks base. Here is the new requirement based on customer feedback: 

Each of the patches needs to be revisited (commit list attached). If it just added functionality  then all is needed is some #ifdef added. If it replaced, deleted, or modified the code  then the original code needs to be put back and the TI code #ifdef. I dont need a meeting for that.

#ifdef OMAP_ENHANCEMENT

|Patch Set 8: No score; No score

We need to isolate our change in Google areas, specifically in frameworks base. Here is the new requirement based on customer feedback: 

Each of the patches needs to be revisited (commit list attached). If it just added functionality  then all is needed is some #ifdef added. If it replaced, deleted, or modified the code  then the original code needs to be put back and the TI code #ifdef. I dont need a meeting for that. 



We will use the define  OMAP_ENHANCEMENT. So the code would look like 

#ifdef OMAP_ENHANCEMENT 

&lt;some nice ti change&gt; 

#else 

&lt;previous Android (assuming the change modified the original code) 

#endif 



Android.mk files in affected areas will need to have the following in it 

Ifneq (,$(findstring omap, $(TARGET_BOARD_PLATFORM))) 

LOCAL_CFLAGS += -DOMAP_ENCHANCEMENT 

endif 


Please rework as appropriate.
|Patch Set 9: Verified; Looks good to me, approved

|Patch Set 4: No score; I would prefer that you didn't submit this

We need to isolate our change in Google areas, specifically in frameworks base.  Here is the new requirement based on customer feedback:

Each of the patches needs to be revisited (commit list attached).  If it just added functionality  then all is needed is some #ifdef added.  If it replaced, deleted, or modified the code  then the original code needs to be put back and the TI code #ifdef.  I dont need a meeting for that.

 

We will use the define  OMAP_ENHANCEMENT.  So the code would look like

#ifdef OMAP_ENHANCEMENT

&lt;some nice ti change&gt;

#else

&lt;previous Android (assuming the change modified the original code)

#endif

 

Android.mk files in affected areas will need to have the following in it

Ifneq (,$(findstring omap, $(TARGET_BOARD_PLATFORM)))

LOCAL_CFLAGS += -DOMAP_ENCHANCEMENT

endif


Please rework as appropriate.

|Patch Set 2:

Ricky I can confirm that this happens on OMAP4.  I can reproduce it easily.
|Patch Set 2:

The issue that I see is the following (just in case it isn't clear to others):

You fast forward or rewind the playback (mp3 or AV) and when you resume at the new position, you get a small portion of playback from the previous position.  Pausing the clip is unnecessary but highlights the problem.

To reproduce:  take any mp3 or AV playback that you know well.  Fast forward to a very noisy and distinct part of the clip.  Then seek back to a different position (you can use pause just to make it easier -- it makes no difference).  You will hear a very small portion of sound from the &quot;noisy distinct part of the clip&quot; before you hear the sound from the new part of the clip start up.  Using pause makes it easier to hear but makes no difference to reproducing it since you can do it just with the seek.

Just for information:  a different algorithm is used during the merge process.  Consequently, a git pull can succeed and a merge fail.  I usually hide this from the developers and rebase the patches that fail the merge.  Keith does not.

|Patch Set 1: Do not submit

I can't accept a 2370 line patch.  Break this up into the original Froyo patches.  We need to maintain the history.

|Patch Set 1:

Julian there are 3725 lines of change over approproximately 70 lines of files (not including the files that have been added).

This change is too big for anyone to effectively review or comprehend.

From a customer perspective, I have no idea which patches from Froyo have been ported to Gingerbread.  I have no idea which ones have been modified and how.  If I have rejected a few patches from Froyo, I have no idea what to do to match up the Gingerbread environment with this environment.

From a debugging perspective, I can't revert portions of this patch if there is a problem with it.

This patch is too big.

The correct way to port is to maintain the patch history, port each patch and modify each one as you go.
|Patch Set 1:

Muthu, what is your opinion on this?
|Patch Set 1: No score

Jean

built - no sanity test
|Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.
|Patch Set 4: (3 inline comments)

Tons of Google Code Standard errors in the code.  Essentially single line if statements are not allowed.  There are tons in all the files.

Here are the coding standards:  http://source.android.com/source/code-style.html

Specifically I'm referring to:
http://source.android.com/source/code-style.html#use-standard-brace-style
|Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Please reformat into Google coding standards.
|Patch Set 4:

Those are Java Coding standards that are used throughout the Android code.  If you read through Google code, they are used for C, C++  and Java code.
|Patch Set 4:

Alberto, no sorry I don't have a script that does it yet.
|Patch Set 5:

Thanks very much Alberto....it took longer to skim through the code than it did to comply.

Tony, I used your command and found only 1799 instances of a if statement without a { at the end -- I took the wc -l off your comment and I gave up looking through them at 294 lines.  All of the lines to that point either single line if or else if statements with the exception of a couple of lines with if the comments.  So the coding standards were still maintained.  Single line if statements are allowed -- just not ifs with the line underneath included without bracket/braces around it.
|Patch Set 5:

Because I may not have been clear:

if (condition) do this; 

is allowed

if (condition)
   do this;

is not.

The ones from Google matched:  if (condition) do this;
|Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, approved

Thanks very much Alberto!

|Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

No OMAP_ENHANCEMENTs in the patch.  Please refer to the following page:

 

https://gforge01.dal.design.ti.com/gf/project/omapandroid/wiki/?pagename=OMAP_ENHANCEMENT+code+usage

|Patch Set 3: (11 inline comments)

I've marked areas in the java code which do not have OMAP_ENHANCEMENT in the code.  They should be in OMAP_ENHANCMENT.

XML files can be tackled by overlays if they don't apply to all boards; hence, the question.  However, they must apply in all scenarios if an overlay is not the solution.  So it must work on Panda and customers boards.

Please refer to the following page:

https://gforge01.dal.design.ti.com/gf/project/omapandroid/wiki/?pagename=OMAP_ENHANCEMENT+code+usage

|Patch Set 4:

When using acronyms in descriptions, please ensure that you have expanded it at least in one of the usages.  I'm assuming that a PLD is a programmable logic device. 

In computer science many acronyms have multiple meanings so expanding the first usage helps to eliminate confusion.  

Here's how I would re-write your note:  

Note: Programmable Logic Devices (PLDs) are platform dependent. The original implementation treats the cache line size as 64 bytes.  With this modification and additional PLDs, bionic memory throughput increases for L2 cache from 1597 MB/s to 2674 MB/s for 64 KB data.
|Patch Set 4:

(11 inline comments)

Okay the biggest problem here seems to be that you are using an editor which replaces tabs with spaces.  I would turn that feature off in the editor and then rework the patch to get rid of all the lines in the change that have nothing to do with the actual change that you are doing.

It looks like you have reworked the real changes that you have done correctly.

Take all the tabs rework out because is it done poorly and then redo that in a later patch.

That way, this patch concentrates in on the actual fix done.

|Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

On a previous discussion on FaceUnlock, the following statement was provided by Akshay Agarwal:

Note that this cannot be delivered to customers. This is part of the GMS package and OEMs should have their own GMS package from Google.

I'm going loop Akshay in on this patch.  Putting into -1 for now until I hear back from him.
|Patch Set 2:

I can't find Akshay as a user in the system.  I'll have to pursue this via email.
|Patch Set 2: No score

I've received a reply on the previous FaceUnlock email chain from Anand Gadiyar:

The face-unlock APK is the one that cannot be delivered. This comes from the GMS package that Akshay mentioned. This package needs to be obtained by customers directly from google - the xmls that were uploaded in this patch are not part of GMS.

Anything we do in our AFS code to enable face-unlock should be fine.

On a separate note, thanks for pointing out the patch - I was wondering why face unlock doesn't work on our devices yet :)

|Patch Set 9: Fails


|Patch Set 10:

Do we have a coding standard from Google for HWC?
|Patch Set 10:

When you are programming, that can be a reasonable approach.  When you are integrating over the entire Android File system, then you are dealing with at least 20 trees and sometimes 40 to 60 patches in a day and reading each individual file to try to figure out the coding standard for each file is not a reasonable approach. 

Ideally we will get an automatic coding standard checker in place at some point -- that will never be able to read the code to find out the coding standard.  It would just reject the file automatically.

I have proposed in an email to you that files which do not follow the Android Coding Standards have a line at the top below the license that indicates the standard used.  That way, we can have any automatic checker search for that in the file, and it will know not to automatically reject the file.  

Obviously this will only apply to files in which we collaborate with third parties who have their own coding standards for the files.  Otherwise, we would expect the files to comply with Android Coding Standards.

This approach would enable an automatic checker to be developed and also allow for integrators and developers to have a quick way to check a file for a different coding standard.
|Patch Set 10:

The problem with applying new standards to any new modules is that this makes it more difficult to push any new modules up to Android in the future.  

Android Coding Standards will apply unless a third party is involved and code is being passed back and forth.

|Uploaded patch set 12.

|Patch Set 1:

I see build errors for OMAP3 relating due to the inclusion of
these flags: 
CONFIG_TOUCHSCREEN_SYNTM12XX=y CONFIG_TWL6040_VIB=y

And these flags are selected by: 
MACH_OMAP_4430SDP [=y] &amp;&amp; ARCH_OMAP4 [=y]
|Patch Set 1: No score; No score

In arch/arm/configs/android_4430_defconfig:
CONFIG_HAS_EARLYSUSPEND=y

In drivers/input/touchscreen/syntm12xx.c:
#ifdef CONFIG_HAS_EARLYSUSPEND
#include &lt;linux/earlysuspend.h&gt;
#endif

Build error for omap3:
drivers/input/touchscreen/syntm12xx.c:316: error: field 'early_suspend' has incomplete type
make[3]: *** [drivers/input/touchscreen/syntm12xx.o] Error 1
make[2]: *** [drivers/input/touchscreen] Error 2
make[1]: *** [drivers/input] Error 2
make: *** [drivers] Error 2

To get rid of this build error, I would have to enable CONFIG_HAS_EARLYSUSPEND=y in omap3_defconfig

Is this fine?
|Patch Set 1:

@Vikram: Yes, that helped. One reference to struct early_suspend was missing this check #ifdef CONFIG_HAS_EARLYSUSPEND.Will create a new patch and submit it.
|Patch Set 1:

I also see a linking error relating to drivers/misc/twl6040-vib.c

drivers/built-in.o: In function `vib_remove':
/omap/drivers/misc/twl6040-vib.c:227: undefined reference to `timed_output_dev_unregister'
drivers/built-in.o: In function `vib_probe':
/omap/drivers/misc/twl6040-vib.c:195: undefined reference to `timed_output_dev_register'
/omap/drivers/misc/twl6040-vib.c:212: undefined reference to `timed_output_dev_unregister'
make: *** [.tmp_vmlinux1] Error 1

This is because the ANDROID_TIMED_OUTPUT is not defined and we are not compiling drivers/staging/android/timed_output.c and drivers/staging/android/timed_output.h

Can I enclose references to timed_output_dev_register and timed_output_dev_unregister within a check #ifdef ANDROID_TIMED_OUTPUT ?

|Patch Set 2:

Since you are removing the check on force_mem_out in isp_csi2_try_pipeline(), do we need to have it defined in isp_cs2.h? Or should we move it to isp.h as that is the only other place we are using it: 
drivers/media/video/isp/isp.c	
2295 a-&gt;value = isp-&gt;isp_csi2.force_mem_out ? 1 : 0;
2348 isp-&gt;isp_csi2.force_mem_out = new_value ? true : false;
|Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve


|Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)


|Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Atanas, this check &quot;if (previous_power == V4L2_POWER_ON)&quot; is required to prevent disabling the clock if the power state is OFF or standby. If you remove this check, you may see a warning during suspend-resume.
|Patch Set 1:

Atanas, removing this check will cause the suspend-resume path to fail; we have seen this happen. You can test it at your end and verify.

To answer your question:
When you transition from V4L2_POWER_ON to V4L2_POWER_STANDBY, we check if prev power state was ON and then disable cam_mclk.

When you transition from V4L2_POWER_STANDBY to V4L2_POWER_OFF, the cam_mclk was already disabled, so no need to decrement the usecount; as it is already 0.
|Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

If you plan to separate out the case for V4L2_POWER_STANDBY and V4L2_POWER_OFF, then that is fine. It does make sense to have separate logic for both.
|Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

|Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve


|Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve


|Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

24 and 33 seem redundant as well as 25 fps gets selected when you request for 24 and 30 gets selected when you ask for 33.
The only way to actually get 5, 24 or 33 fps is if we skip the negotiation process and set the fps directly using the set param ioctl.

|Patch Set 1:

James, there is a fastboot.sh in device/ti/omap5sevm/boot
|Patch Set 1:

I think it should be possible to have just one to support all versions of silicon.
|Patch Set 2:

how about you have an api to get_boot_slot() which returns back the device and use that when we make a call to the rom_mmc apis? that way you dont have to declare device in eboot.
|Patch Set 2:

Adding what we discussed here -
Instead of using a function like board_flash_slot_init() to setup device=something, have two functions like get_boot_slot() and set_boot_slot() and setup device=something in the board files outside of an API.
get_boot_slot() can be used before we need to read the device and set_boot_slot() can be used to set the device based on user preference.
|Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

|Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

verified with UEVM.

With head p-master-dev:
sudo ./fastboot flash boot boot.img followed by sudo ./fastboot flash ramdisk ramdisk.img doesnt work

With this patch on top of p-master-dev:
sudo ./fastboot flash boot boot.img followed by sudo ./fastboot flash ramdisk ramdisk.img works.

|Uploaded patch set 15.
|Uploaded patch set 2.
|Uploaded patch set 3.
|Uploaded patch set 4.
|Uploaded patch set 5.
|Patch Set 5:

Aneesh to answer your Q, &quot;Is it not better to decide between NO_INIT_USB and INIT_USB depending on the boot mode rather than whether it's iboot or eboot. Why not allow eboot to work in peripheral preferred bootmode and iboot to work in memory preferred boot mode.&quot;

As of today, iboot only gets used with usbboot i.e. in peripheral boot mode and eboot only gets used in memory boot mode. In peripheral boot mode, we can reuse the existing usb connection and hence don't need to init the usb, so NO_INIT_USB is being used.

There are some changes being made to support the 2 stage boot and it's possible that your comment will apply there.
For now though, since iboot is only used in one mode, I thought it best to keep the changes simple.
|Patch Set 5:

Aneesh, I believe we answered some part of this Q on email today. We don't support Windows flashing. You may make changes as needed to support the use-case you want. Otherwise, we recommend using omapflash on Windows.

|Patch Set 1:

Dan, the only way to access this proc_get_proc_id would be through boot_ops. I tried passing in boot_ops to the set_flash_slot api. The return type of set_flash_slot() is storage_ops which gets called in fastboot.c
The problem is fasboot used fbdata so when I return boot_ops-&gt;storage ops to fbdata-&gt;storage_ops, the compiler complains.

|I do not understand why this change is required to remove access of L4 access for DSS. How is this related to the patch description? According to the description, I would expect omap44xx_l4_per__dss to be removed. Pls correct me if I am wrong.
|The idea of adding OCP_USER_MPU is to ensure that the DSS registers access is done through L3 interconnect. If this flag is not defined then only L4 interconnect is used. 

Other way to do this is to  remove omap44xx_l4_per_hwmod but this need not be done as this file is auto-generated and L4 access is available in the hardware. Hence hwmod database shall still continue to have omap44xx_l4_per_hwmod.
|omap5 check is not required as the board file passes the required i2c client info which would not be there for non OMAP5 boards.
|hdmi_ip_data is used only for HDMI Registers details. The phy value that is being passed is a clock value and is not used across many functions. It is used only here and in hdmi_power_on() from where hdmi_ti_4xxx_phy_init() is called. Hence I think that it is not required to be part of hdmi_ip_data struct but can be passed as a parameter.
|Wondering why r shall be made zero. Any harm if returned as error?

Because of r made zero, sync_drop might not happen if sync object is there even though the composition has failed. If sync object is not there, the caller will not get to know that the composition apply failed.

|I guess you did not notice the &quot;for&quot; loop. Within for loop we would be acquiring the lock and without releasing it we will try to acquire it again. Also we cannot do spinlock outside for loop as that is the original implementation.

|Yes, we keep trying if authentication fails, but when a new start frame cb happens, we cancel the previous waiting work and restart. We cannot just leave it if authentication fails. Until the next power on call, we need to keep checking if KSVlist again arrived. Anyways I am sending a patch separately to slightly modify this infinite loop approach. |With patch http://review.omapzoom.org/#/c/26779/ condition (d-&gt;num_ovls == 0) is not required as this condition is handled at FB level. When (d-&gt;num_ovls == 0) is removed from here early suspend works. 

I could not test with HDMI as default display with the above mentioned change as it is still not functional on OMAP5 sEVM board.

As mentioned before dsscomp_early_suspend operates with d-&gt;num_ovls = 0 and d-&gt;num_mgrs = 0. If d-&gt;num_ovls = 1 in dsscomp_early_suspend(), it requires a manger id and hence blank cannot happen.

|typo &quot;comming&quot;
|Murali, Sreenidhi, I don't understand your point. This value is updated only in this function and I am protecting it with a mutex when the process updates it. When some other process enters this function, it would read the value and return error. Why do we need to lock the entire function? How can two calls go through if only one process can update the variable at a time and the same variable is verified before doing any operations. Kindly clarify.
|As discussed, this mutex lock is required. The reason is that the HDCP-encrypt daemon would be initiated by any user (it is supposed to be after boot). If mistakenly it is run twice, this ioctl would be called. Hence in order to have protection in kernel side, we need this variable. But this need not be hdcp-&gt;lock. It can be some other lock not part of HDCP driver structure. So I am moving this lock mechanism directly in the ioctl call as Sreenidhi requested and rename the same. But the logic would remain the same.

|Yes, in case there was a previous workqueue due to interrupt, but by the time work gets scheduled, say HPD is detected (disable &amp; enable). For this kind of scenario, it is required to cancel the previous work, if any. There is no harm in doing it during power_on and it is safe.

|until
|In HDCP, since WQ is sequential, flush WQ is not reuired. But as per cancel_delayed_work() func, flushing is required as del_timer does not happen in cancel_delayed_work(). Instead if you use __cancel_delayed_work, flushing is not required at all.
|Better to do a flush_workqueue() after cancel_delayed_work()
|Why are you using __cancel_delayed_work here and cancel_delayed_work in the other place? Since you do not check for the return value, I guess that it is better to use either one of them consistently.
|Logically different. Don't delete the extra line here.
|Still we will not be doing dispc clock source switching in dsi_init() as it happens before LCD_EN programming. Atleast dispc clock source switching has to be done in *_post function. Hence only lcd_clk source switching can be done in dsi_init(). But with this approach, the WA handling for CDDS bug OMAP5430-1.0BUG01565  will be completely addressed in dsi_handle_lcd_en_timing_pre() and dsi_handle_lcd_en_timing_post() functions itself.

For non OMAP5 ES1.0, these functions are ignored.
For OMA5ES1.0, when the LCD CLK and DISPC FCLK sources are configured different in board file, the workwround already in place is sufficient.

With this patch, when LCD and DISPC FCLK sources are configured the same in board file, the OMAP5 ES1.0 clock sources selection is as follows:
While enabling DSS:
    -NO clock source switching during dsi_init() and PRCM is the clock source
    -In dsi_handle_lcd_en_timing_pre(), select lcd clock source as per board file configuration and program LCD_EN.
    -Do DSS manager enable
    -In dsi_handle_lcd_en_timing_post(), select dispc clock source as per board file configuration . Now both clock sources are as per board file configuration.
    -Display data

While disabling DSS:
    -NO clock source switching during dsi_init() and the clock source is as per board file configuration and are same.
    -In dsi_handle_lcd_en_timing_pre(), select PRCM as lcd clock source and program LCD_EN.
    -Do DSS manager enable
    -In dsi_handle_lcd_en_timing_post(), select PRCM as dispc clock source. Now both clock sources are at PRCM

Checking DSS_STATUS value is only an extra check as we do LCD_EN programming as soon as select lcd clock source is called.

|mutex_destroy is missing
|at err, you would free up channel 0 &amp; 1 even though the request returned error
|at err, you would free up channel 1 which is not yet reuested

|Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Had an internal discussion and it seems to be proper change. It would be great, if the description of the errata is provided in the patch description to avoid confusions.
|Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

The idea of adding OCP_USER_MPU is to ensure that the DSS registers access is done through L3 interconnect. If this flag is not defined then only L4 interconnect is used.

Other way to do this is to remove omap44xx_l4_per_hwmod but this need not be done as this file is auto-generated and L4 access is available in the hardware. Hence hwmod database shall still continue to have omap44xx_l4_per_hwmod.
|Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

The idea of adding OCP_USER_MPU is to ensure that the DSS registers access is done through L3 interconnect. If this flag is not defined then only L4 interconnect is used.

Other way to do this is to remove omap44xx_l4_per_hwmod but this need not be done as this file is auto-generated and L4 access is available in the hardware. Hence hwmod database shall still continue to have omap44xx_l4_per_hwmod.
|Uploaded patch set 4.
|Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Updated patch description as per the comments
|Patch Set 4: No score

Dan, This patch makes all the the dss driver's register access through L3 interconnect. But in omap44xx_dss_reset(), there is a hard coding of base address which accesses L4 interconnect registers. The patch at
http://review.omapzoom.org/#/c/20138/
fixes the omap44xx_dss_reset() accessing L4 interconnect.

IMO, both the patches are required to address the errata i733.

|Uploaded patch set 2.
|Patch Set 2: Verified


|Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

hdmi_ip_data is used only for HDMI Registers details. The phy value that is being passed is a clock value and is not used across many functions. It is used only here and in hdmi_power_on() from where hdmi_ti_4xxx_phy_init() is called. Hence I think that it is not required to be part of hdmi_ip_data struct but can be passed as a parameter.
|Uploaded patch set 3.
|Patch Set 3: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Updated the patch for the latest p-android-omap-3.0 HEAD.

Regarding Dan's previous comment of making phy to be part of hdmi_ip_data struct, here is my explanation:

hdmi_ip_data struct is used only for HDMI Registers details. The phy value that is being passed is a clock value and is not used across many functions. It is used only here and in hdmi_power_on() from where hdmi_ti_4xxx_phy_init() is called. 

Hence I think that it is not required to be part of hdmi_ip_data struct but can be passed as a parameter.

|Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Without this patch ION test cases and DSSCOMP UT cases won't pass and would result in bus error mentioned below. This happens when a read is attempted on some ion mapped tiler memory area. This patch fixes the same. No CQ defect available for this.

135&#124;root@android:/data # ./iontest --map -t -w 1920 -h 1080 -r 2
test 1, len 1048576, width 1920, height 1080 fmt 2 align 0, map_flags 1, prot 3, alloc_flags 0
[ 1129.735046] Unhandled fault: external abort on non-linefetch (0x1008) at 0x4009f010
Bus error

|Patch Set 3: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Sreenidhi, the user would have no clue when the display goes dark. User will not be able to find the brightness adjustment bar as the screen becomes dark. Hence I think this patch is required for maintaining the minimum brightness.
|Patch Set 3:

The spec sheet from LG is incomplete and we are already in discussion with them to understand the issue. Will revert this hack once we fix the issue.
|Uploaded patch set 4.
|Patch Set 4: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve


|Patch Set 4:

Praneeth, this hack is required because once we have brightness control from Android UI, setting value of less than 147 would make the screen dark and the user would not be able to see anything on the screen until the user identifies the brightness bar blindly and bring it back to &gt;147 value. Hence this patch is a must until we get this issue resolved.

As of now, LG is yet to come back with reply to our queries. It has been over a week that the thread has started. I don't expect this to be resolved very soon.

If we are going to consider brightness control as a required feature, we need to live with this hack for a little time until we get pointers from LG (we are following it up aggressively).
|Patch Set 4:

This patch is pushed to

https://gitorious.org/linux-omap-display/linux-omap-display/commits/omap5_platform_base_v3.1-pm-dss

|Uploaded patch set 11.
|Patch Set 12: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

No change
|Patch Set 12:

Why specifically binary sysfs attribute?

Please note that this sysfs is used by hwc to read the EDID values. The same sysfs attribute is used in K3.0 and there is big NACK for changing the interface (pls check previous versions of this series). Hence we will not change this.
|Patch Set 12:

Please check &quot;handle_s3d_hotplug&quot; in hardware/ti/omap4xxx/hwc/hwc.c to find out how this is handled. This is not for the user to read sysfs for reading edid values. FYI, when HDMI cable is connected, there is a default print of EDID values with which user can read the EDID values.

As I mentioned before there is no plan to change the sysfs interface for s3d as it affects hwc and K3.0 kernel (OMAP4). We are making use of the same sysfs interface as used in OMAP4.
|Patch Set 12:

Please let us know the reason for why we need to use binary attribute only?

I do not find any other sysfs using binary attribute in DSS. Are there any advantage in binary attribute compared to a string attribute? How is it going to make a difference in S3D handling? Thanks for clarifying.
|Patch Set 12:

A quick try by making it a binary attribute results in HWC crashes. Dumping the contents and verifying the values was fine, but hwc crash has to be debugged. (Thanks to Nikola for testing this during his week long holiday).

Looks like the way HWC reads the EDID has to be accordingly changed? We will experiment these changes separately and send a separate patch for the same. 

As mentioned, if there are any changes in hwc for the same which would affect K3.0, we would not do the changes but we will keep you posted. We can take this forward in email discussion.

Also can you please clarify what is the disadvantage in having human readable attribute for this sysfs (which is working seamlessly in OMAP4 and tested working on OMAP5)? Any specific issues foreseen?

Sreenidhi, this is self explanatory in the patch. num_ovls passed is checked for  greater than and size of ARRAY_SIZE(u.m.ovl) (which is the max no of overlays) and error is returned. Actually it should return error only if it exceeds the size and not if it is equal to the size.
