|Should &quot;mHwDev-&gt;mMixer.setPath(mDevices, true)&quot; also be called here?
|Ok, understood.
|Should &quot;mHwDev-&gt;mMixer.setPath(mDevices, false)&quot; also be called here?
|&quot;passing&quot; instead of &quot;pass&quot;
|&quot;registered&quot; instead of &quot;register&quot;
|&quot;writing&quot; instead of &quot;write&quot;
|&quot;registered&quot; instead of &quot;register&quot;
|&quot;extracting&quot; instead of &quot;extract&quot;
|&quot;copying&quot; instead of &quot;copy&quot;
|&quot;copying&quot; instead of &quot;copy&quot;
|&quot;writing&quot; instead of &quot;write&quot;, and &quot;underlying&quot; instead of &quot;undelying&quot;
|Is return value true/false? The prototype shows int.
|The way that the java and native size are written, stop is called multiple times even if the app doesn't explicitly call stop twice. This is because the native finalize will result in stop being called, to make sure it is stopped before releasing the resources. So, it would come as a warning every time, even if the user is following the proper procedure and might be confusing.
|I think this is a similar scenario as what would happen with the original code, if the only supported device for an input was disconnected. In that case, getDeviceForInputSource() would return AUDIO_DEVICE_NONE, and the input would keep the same device, even though it was disconnected. I was trying to keep with similar logic as what was present before.

I can add the warning/error message.
|Yes, that's true, this is redundant. I'll remove this line.
|Good point. We should also check here to make sure the new device is not already in use before updating to the new device. I will make the changes.
|This is checking to see if the input frame size is equal to the number of source channels being merged. You could, for example, have an input frame size of 6 channels, but only be using 4 of those channels to merge to the output. In that case, you wouldn't want to use the &quot;merge_4_mult&quot; path.
|should this be &quot;ti,multichannel-shared&quot;?
|possible typo? maybe &quot;when&quot; is not needed here?
|You are right, it should not do the NOT operation when zoneValue is -1. Default zoneValue should be 0, and then if it is set to -1 (indicating that it is legacy), then zoneValue should be set to the cabin zone. Then the NOT operation can be done. I will fix it.
|I thought that dispatchAudioFocusChange() needed zoneValue to be -1, but checking the AudioManager code, it looks like only zoneFlag needs to be -1. I can make this change.
|Ok, I can add a trace.
|Yes, it's still valid. It was removed from the stack, but the fse entry still exists at this point. It is the same as what is being done in removeFocusStackEntry() above.
|zoneValue is relevant to dispatchAudioFocusChange also, but only if zoneFlag is -1. If zoneValue is -1, then zoneFlag is also -1, meaning that the zone info passed to dispatchAudioFocusChange() is not used, which means it is using &quot;legacy&quot;, or only the main cabin zone.
|This is to reset abandonAudioFocusZone after the removeFocusStackEntry() call, since with this patch, abandonAudioFocusZone is used outside of notifyTopOfAudioFocusStack(). removeFocusStackEntry() now uses abandonAudioFocusZone to decide whether to remove the stack entry or not. And removeFocusStackEntry() is called from more places than just here.
|In exit_voice_call(), audio_route_reset_path() is called. In case of failure in enter_voice_call, should audio_route_reset_path() also be called?
|ret is already 0 here, does it need to be set again? or perhaps ret should be initialized to -1?
|In this case, even if signed_frames is &lt; 0, ret is set to 0. It doesn't look like signed_frames will be less than zero, but ret may not need to be set here.
|With the code as it is, this will never be false.

|Good catch. I think this should actually be (!obj-&gt;late_attach &#124;&#124; obj-&gt;domain) instead of (!obj-&gt;late_attach &amp;&amp; !obj-&gt;domain). The idea here was to not call the deassert if we are performing late attach before iommu attaching is complete, but that we will call the deassert even if late attach is true after attaching is complete (indicated by the domain no longer being NULL).
|It looks like the code for IPU1 is already in this patch as well. What prevents IPU1 support also?

|Perhaps break this into two patches, one that adds the late attach feature, and a second one that adds this to the dra7xx_evm config file.

|Since this is in common code, will this function work for omap5 also?
|True. In upstream u-boot this has been corrected to use dieid 0 and 1 (https://patchwork.ozlabs.org/patch/454086/). The implementation in this patch, however, is done to match what is already in the fastboot and regular (non-ssb) Android boot in the current branch. Perhaps a separate patch could change this in all 3 locations so that it will be in sync?
|Just trying to match non-ssb case, which passes a mach-type when booting the kernel (see line 271 in this file).
|Why add a new config option? Can we reuse SPL_USB_BOOT_SUPPORT, which is what is currently being used for adding peripheral boot support?
|I think the additional 16KB memory usage might be a good thing to note in the commit message also, since it changes the amount of usable CMA pool.
|This is now being defined for both late attach and non-late attach cases, meaning that cmd_elf.o will get compiled in in both cases. Is that needed?
|same comment as dra7xx_evm.h
|If lateattach.c is only compiling when CONFIG_LATE_ATTACH is defined, then this is not true.
|OK, that is interesting. Then probably the sequence in &quot;ARM: DRA7: Add Workaround for DRA7 DSP MFLAG Errata i872
add0afa84900e89595bfe1e6999b42b719031bcb&quot; needs to be fixed to first power on the DSPs and then put them back to power off when done. It was assumed based on the TRM that the DSPs would already be in power ON state.
|From my understanding, the DSP cores would not have been in power OFF state. The the default state at boot is to be in power ON state but with clocks disabled and resets asserted.
|A little more background on what feature this patch is adding would be helpful here. Some more info like what is the feature and an overview of how it is implemented.
|is this used?
|Can this commented line be removed?
|comment style doesn't match rest of file which uses &quot;/*&quot; style for function descriptions
|align with rest of params
|tabs
|Should put mutex protection around this section to protect the callbackmsg[] array for the case where multiple VIDDEC3_create calls happen concurrently.
|Should this pass if outputDataMode is not IVIDEO_NUMROWS?
|tabs
|this could be a warning instead of an error. It is a valid case for the codec not to use row_mode, right?
|May not want to leave your name in the debug traces
|why create the MmRpcCallbackHandle here instead of during VIDDEC3_create?
|I'm not sure I follow the semaphore logic. I see that a sem_post is done here to start the callback. But why is a sem_post done from within the callback after every MmRpc_call?
|putDataFlag is also set to 0 in the callback when a full frame is done. Does it also need to be set here? Is this done for handling the error case, in case process returns before a full frame is decoded?
|should post the sem here to wake the thread to handle the exit request?
|Why do QNX changes require changes in Linux/Android? Is it the SYS/BIOS DSP Radio/APPE application that has an updated sr0 address and now the dts file needs to match?
|OK, can you mention that in the commit message? From this it sounds like the change is to align with QNX, but really it is to align with the SYS/BIOS Radio/APPE application, right?
|In the kernel this is defined as 0x20000000 (IPU virt address for L2 SRAM). See omap_remoteproc.c &quot;OMAP_RPROC_IPU_L2RAM_DEV_ADDR&quot;.
|Ditto above
|Should check for valid rsc-&gt;pa returned and return error if unable to allocate
|Should check for valid pa and return error if unable to allocate.
|Should check for valid pa and return error if unable to allocate.
|spl_load_cores() should be called from here also for QSPI boot
|This type is deprecated in k4.x version of remoteproc. The updated remoteproc.h in the kernel mentions this in the structure. Can this file be updated to match?
|Yes, it is for Y and UV. Good point. In fact, I can probably just pass the one for both Y and UV, since the codec doesn't actually use the buffers, just checks for NULL-ness. I only have to pass a valid value so that dce/rpmsg-rpc can do the proper translation. I will try with using only one buffer.
|When error recovery happens, we need to release all handles to /dev/rpmsg-dce. This is required because all open handles are marked as &quot;stale&quot; by rpmsg-rpc when error recovery is performed. The handles won't be usable again. And until the last handle is released, a new one won't be opened by MmRpc.

Is the concern that we may leak memory with the opening and closing?

If we cannot close this handle cleanly here, then Media needs to be stopped and restarted in order to decode another video after error recovery.
|This was added to keep alignment with Android and also as a placeholder for future use by Linux. I forgot about QNX, thanks for pointing this out. I put it in libdce.h since the rest of these prototypes were in that file. If we don't see any possibility that other OSes may use something similar in the future, then I can keep the changes exclusively for Android and remove this.
|Please align with the rest of the struct
|Please align with the rest of the struct.
|Please align with the rest of the struct.
|Please align with the rest of the struct.

|Could you add a little more detail in the commit message? Maybe mention which address is chosen and what it is used for.
|Does this need to be changed to ALOGE?
|should be aligned with rest of code
|With the change to ioremap the pagetable for all late attach cases, you don't need this check for &quot;late_attach_dma_pool&quot; anymore when unmapping the pagetable. It should be removed so that the memory is unmapped appropriately.
|This definition looks the same as iopgd_page_paddr(). Do we need this?
|Where are these unmapped?
Since we know that in the late attach case, these all exist in contiguous memory, can we leverage that into doing a single ioremap (sometime during initialization) instead of doing this for each entry?
|This definition looks the same as iopte_index(da). Do we need this?
|Yes, that is a good point. Although looking at the OSAL_DeleteTask() code, it never returns OSAL_ErrNotReady, so this code may not be reachable.

|Patch Set 4:

I tested the page table dump after late attach and also after error recovery, which results in reloading of the image. In both cases I see the page table info. I do see that the page table is slightly different for loading from u-boot versus loading from kernel, though. Remoteproc seems to be programming smaller sizes whereas u-boot always programs in 1MB sections.

|Patch Set 3:

&gt;&gt;Is there a way to communicate the memory locations used for the pagetables to the kernel instead of creating a new carveout?

Even if we communicated this address, how to allocate that specific physical memory from the kernel at runtime? dma_alloc_coherent allocates from the CMA pool but doesn't let you specify the address AFAIK. If the concern is using more memory, then what if we made each of the remote core CMA pools smaller by the size of the iommu table, and created a new DMA pool for each of the iommu table entries?
|Patch Set 3:

On my previous comment, I meant to say &quot;iommu tables&quot; instead of &quot;iommu table entries&quot;.
|Patch Set 3:

In this patch, all memory allocations for remotecores (except for the IOMMU tables) are from CMA pools.

|Extra blank line ??
|In the case &quot;blaze_uart_info&quot; is not populated, the &quot;module level default&quot; will be used for port initialization. The &quot;module level default&quot; has the the power on reset value for the WER. i.e 0x7f ORed value of these events (RLSI&#124;RHRI&#124;RX&#124;DCDCD&#124;RI&#124;DSR&#124;CTS)

The blaze_uart_info is populated to over ride the module level defaults since we want to limit the number of wakeup events to only 4 events.

So for the folks reporting a problem with this limited setting, can choose to either populate this info structure with the wer setting of their choice or use the module default of 0x7F, in which case not populate blaze_uart_info.

The same holds good for other 3 omap_serial_init_port_pads calls.
|In the case &quot;blaze_uart_info&quot; is not populated, the &quot;module level default&quot; will be used for port initialization. The &quot;module level default&quot; has the the power on reset value for the WER. i.e 0x7f ORed value of these events (RLSI&#124;RHRI&#124;RX&#124;DCDCD&#124;RI&#124;DSR&#124;CTS)

The blaze_uart_info is populated to over ride the module level defaults since we want to limit the number of wakeup events to only 4 events.

So for the folks reporting a problem with this limited setting, can choose to either populate this info structure with the wer setting of their choice or use the module default of 0x7F, in which case not populate blaze_uart_info.

The same holds good for other 3 omap_serial_init_port_pads calls.
|If after 5 retries, the BT chip is still not asleep, you are allowing it to suspend.
Is this acceptable ?. since you are not spinning in code is is a better idea to use &quot;if-then&quot; instead ?
|Agree, the effect is the same if it is while or if.. it is more of coding style comment.
Perhaps the compilers used will optimize to the same either way but a &quot;while()&quot; needs more setup for a typical ISA vs a really simply if-then.

Also, it is not clear how much time is equivalent to 5 retries.  If 5 retries are done in a a fraction of a second, it is no good. The answer to this may lie in the application acceptance which I don't know about and should come directly from the BT application requirement.
|Must initialize retry_suspend to zero, else the first time this is called this is at risk for not functioning as expected.
Change line 123 to
static unsigned short retry_suspend = 0;
|The idea here was to not block till the console is locked.
My understanding of the usleep_range() function call is that if no other even causes a wakeup in the system between 100 and 300 usec, it will time out at 300 usec and check for console lock.
Do you propose something else ?

Thank you
|Please clarify,
I did not notice where in this code the clock status is being mandated.

Thank you

|Djamil,
Looking at at the omap_hwmod.c file, it seems to me that the .off value is not relevent.

the .off value will come into question only when the pad state is _HWMOD_STATE_DISABLED and that state is set only at shutdown.
Also to validate this  I put debug code in this piece of code case 
mux.c 
_HWMOD_STATE_DISABLED:
			/* Use safe mode unless OMAP_DEVICE_PAD_REMUX */
			if (flags &amp; OMAP_DEVICE_PAD_REMUX) {
				if (!strcmp(pad-&gt;name, &quot;usbb1_ulpitll_dir.usbb1_ulpiphy_dir&quot;)) {
					printk(&quot;#RK: MUX: disabled , value written is %x\n&quot;, pad-&gt;off);
				}
				val = pad-&gt;off;
				}

and I never reach this when the device goes into off and out of it.
If you agree we need to ack the patch to make it to merge.
Thanks
Ruchika
|Please see my previous comment
|Why check for just bit 1, From the TRM bit 0 &quot;seems&quot; that is will never get set since values that have bit 0 set are reserved. Designs often have those bits used for corner cases in the design logic. I would prefer it you could just set the whole 2 bit field to 0x2 and then write zero. If there's a specific reason that is avoided please specify.
|1.I like Igor's #define since it follows some naming convention. Why increase the &quot;IN&quot; threshold ?
2.That will not effect your case so might as well leave it to the default of 0x20 ?
Increasing the IN threshold may increase the latency for incoming data (not a use case for audio speakers) but possibly for others.
For other USB devices like mice and keyboards that do IN transfers this value may negatively impact.

3. I fear that 0x40 may not be sufficient for some kind of data streams that still may take more time to decode hence you may still have the same problem but just harder to recreate.
|I don't want to do this since 2 flags vs one will need to be set to enable this path.

Change 
:Synopsys USB device controller requires all OUT transfer request

|Suggestion:
&lt;variable&gt; = req-&gt;length % bulk_out_maxpacket;
if (&lt;variable&gt;)
{
    req-&gt;length += dev-&gt;bulk_out_maxpacket - &lt;variable&gt;;
}
|I would replace &quot;USB3.0 hubs&quot; to &quot;USB3.0 devices&quot;.
Also repplace the last line with.
We analyzed traffic between a USB2.0 PC host and the USB3.0 device and observed that the host does not send PING packets during enumeration.
Turning off PING packets in the OTG host resolves this issue.

238                            offset_corr = (device-&gt;bcdUSB &gt;= 0x300)?USB_DT_SS_EP_COMP_S:0;

240	                            bufptr += USB_DT_ENDPOINT_SIZE + offset_corr;

242	                            bufptr += USB_DT_ENDPOINT_SIZE + offset_corr;

|Here...
|Why set this when us_dma is 0 ?
|The OMAP4 driver had a variable called &quot;suspended&quot; in the port structure and it gets set when the system wide uart suspend handler... and cleared in the system wide resume handler.
In a dsicussion i learnt that the 2 frameworks are kind of independent of each other .. i.e runtime and system wide suspend.

In omap4 the &quot;pm_runtime_suspended()&quot; check was replaced with a &quot;if &quot;up-&gt;suspended)
So thisi s probably why Grygorii is bringing this up. Looking for an agreement so I can close this. For now .. no new patch on this..
|This was an accident.. this function wasn't getting pulled up as a sumbol with the &quot;static&quot; so just for testing it I removed.
This will be put back

the original macro sets .thaw /.poweroff etc.. 
those were unsupported too ?
Just curious.
If we don't have support for anything other than suspend* and resume* in that set, I agree, I will remove it.

|Patch Set 4:

The problem I found is this:-
Case 1: Consider just uart port 1. Afteer the device goes into OFF mode the first time, when it resumes, the registers have lost context and they come back as &quot;0xFF&quot;. Then the wer is restored to whatever the wakeup set desired for the port from the board config file info. 
Case 1: For uart port 1, when BT and or gps is enabled, the st_kim driver is also initialized and so is the omap_start done for the port. With the IRQ handler registered etc in the uart_startup function.  The IRQ handles/clears events.

Case 2: For uart port 1, when neither BT and GpS is enabled, st_kim is not even started and not is the uart_startup done for the port. However the wer restored for the port is still set to something functional and there is nothing registered to handle any events/wiggles on the pins, allowing those events to remain set and preventing the port to go into off mode the second time around.

|Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve


|Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

This works but we need a better solution.
|Patch Set 1:

The EHCI specification recommends the threshold to be 1/4 of the total buffer size. 
1/2 the buffer is for each direction of the endpoint. Doubling the threshold will increase the latency for the subsequent fetch of a packet and it likely impact other drivers.
Dynamically changing it might not be good either.
We need to speak with the sgx folks to see what can be done about the priorty for the remainder of the system since this problem is seen mostly in a situation with continuous display rendering.
|Patch Set 1:

I do not know the latency value.
Also, a correction:-
I was sure I read the packet buffer was divided between both the IN and OUT transfers but that is not accurate.
So a threshold of 0x40 with a packet buffer of 0x80 means dual buffering vs quad buffering. I don't know if this is ok for every kind of HS/FS usb device that can be connected. 
 
I don't have numbers for latency, maybe Moiz does. 
By &quot;recommendation&quot; I meant the relationship stated in the IP spec, page 204, manly maintaining the ratio between the buffer size and the threshold.

The buffer size of 1K is not supported on the OMAP, since I tried it and a device failed to even enumerate.
|Patch Set 1: No score

This is verified. There seems to be few other options at this time.

|Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Are you sure you don't have to allocate a buffer for a &quot;zero length packet&quot;, from what I understand of the specs, a zero byte data would still need a packet worht allocated.. 
So when he rem == 0 and the length == 0, you may need to have a buffer allocated..

(1 inline comment)

some commit message updates.. else looks good!!
|Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Analyzed usb traffic after the patch and it looks great!!
|Patch Set 2:

The &quot;PING protocol&quot; in USB2.0 is meant for control and bulk endpoints. i is basically a design feature to avoid wastage of bandwidth on the USB bus. When the host has OUT data to send, rather than retrying and attempting out data to the device and being NAK'd if the device does not have the &quot;endpoint size&quot; amount of space, the &quot;PING&quot; was added in USB2.0 to allow the host to PING the device to know whether or not to send the following OUT data. The spec states that USB2.0 devices should  support this which we perceive as high speed devices should support this. Apparently they all don't for the &quot;Control endpoint&quot;, so hosts seem to not send the PING to the devices (as confirmed from a PC host traffic capture) to a USB3.0 device. Hence we followed suit and disabled it in the driver also. We don't expect to break andything and all our testing seems ok so far... needless to say alot of testing is always required for any USB source change. But our traffic looks exaclty like traffic from a regular PC host..
|Patch Set 2:

Actually, I was going to send you a message and ask why we hadn't seen this before.. this is apparently somewhat a known issue.

Is it possible that we have bot tested with enough USB devices in Host mode ? (I actually will check if the EHCI sends PING or not and put the status here so we know.)

If you can point to specifics about this and why this is not good, it would be good since I couldn't locate it.. I was surprised to not find mandates on this for a PC host.

I am exploring to see if there is any status reported from the controller to say a &quot;PING timeout occured&quot; to disable further PINGs to such a device. If such a status is not there then is no other solution. If the host fails some kind of certification with this solution, then we have no choice but to put the particular USB device as an &quot;unsupported device&quot; which I expect will raise eyebrows since every PC can support it... we need to do the right thing.. I'll work on my action items and get back.
|Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

|Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I understand this to be the following :-

Is the transfer is a multiple of the endpoint size (which can be 8/16/64 etc) then a ZLP packet is needed.
So for USB1.1, the endpoint size(maxpacket) can be say 64 but the transfer is say 256 bytes (count) so :-

((count &amp; (dev-&gt;ep_in-&gt;maxpacket - 1)) == 0) {	
            sendZLP = 1;	
  }

does evaluate to true when this is checked at the END of the transfer BUT if this is checked intermediately intermediate counts of 64/128 etc will also evaluate to true and it may an inappropriate  time for zlp packets.

Maybe I am missing something.. please describe exact issue. I did not get the everything from the commit message and the code changes.
|Patch Set 2:

the &quot;maxpacket&quot; fir an endpoint should be equal to the bMaxPacketSize.

After all the device reports the endpoint size to the host PC.

My understanding is you are trying to make the device work wih a USB1.1 Host controller and the USB1.1 specification limits the endpoint size to be 64. If my understanding is correct please read ahead.
Here are my concerns:
1. When the device descriptor reports &quot;bcdUSB&quot; in the device descriptor to be USB210  does the USB1.1 host even enumerate the device ?

2. With a bMaxPacketSize of 512, does the USB1.1 host still continue to enumerate ?

3. I don' think we should even support using a USB1.1 host.

Please ignore if this understanding is all incorrect and please explain or lets have a short call for this. 

I just have a fundamental issue with he maxpacket not being equal to the bMaxpacketSize.
|Patch Set 2:

I would suggest setting the wMaxPacketSize in these fullspeed descirptors to be 64 and try if this works
mtp_fullspeed_in_desc
mtp_fullspeed_out_desc

Ruchika

|Patch Set 3:

Felipe,
This patch does a few things:
1. the request_irq is in the probe.
Don't you thin puting it in startup is suboptimal since every time it starts up the irq is requested vs being already available ?
2. there is a serial_omap_pm function called in the suspend handler which it disables the baud rate clock
3. Removes all he enable_irq and disable_irq. Only one enable_irq is left afer the request of the irq.
If this is not necessary I will remove it.
4  if a free_irq is no necessary in the remove () and automatically taken care of I will fix that.
5. Grygorri mentioned other than suspend_noirq and resume_noirq .. the others are not supported.. I can change that back as well like you have it here and in the patch set previous to this .. but the other changes are necessary.

Please advise.
|Uploaded patch set 4.
|Patch Set 4: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Felipe,
I hope the commit message is clear.
The request_irq change is necessary to go in this patch.
I traced the code to understand the backtrace and realized te following

When OFF mode is attempted he following sequence occurs
-- serial shutdown -&gt; serial_omap_suspend -- &gt; serial_omap_resume-&gt;serial_omap_startup.

Before hiting serial_omap_resume the backtrace is seen since an enable_irq is attempted on a freed irq.

|Patch Set 3:

Paste of the commit that introduced it. It appears that this is required irrespective of DMA usage.
When dma = 1 is tested or enabled, we should check if additional qos constrains enabling needs to be qualified with dma usage. We have this record to come back to. 


commit 2fd149645eb46d26130d7070c6de037dddf34880
Author: Govindraj.R &lt;govindraj.raja@ti.com&gt;
Date:   Wed Nov 9 17:41:21 2011 +0530

    ARM: OMAP2+: UART: Remove omap_uart_can_sleep and add pm_qos
    
    Omap_uart_can_sleep function blocks system wide low power state until
    uart is active remove this func and add qos requests to prevent
    MPU from transitioning.
    
    Keep qos request to default value which will allow MPU to transition
    and while uart baud rate is available calculate the latency value
    from the baudrate and use the same to hold constraint while uart clocks
    are enabled, and if uart is auto-idled the constraint is updated with
    default constraint value allowing MPU to transition.
    
    Qos requests are blocking notifier calls so put these requests to
    work queue, also the driver uses irq_safe version of runtime API's
    and callbacks can be called in interrupt disabled context.
    So to avoid warn on slow path warning while using qos update
    API's from runtime callbacks use the qos_work_queue.
    
    During bootup the runtime_resume call backs might not be called and runtime
    callback gets called only after uart is idled by setting the autosuspend
    timeout. So qos_request from runtime resume callback might not activated during
    boot if uart baudrate is calculated during bootup for console uart, so schedule
    the qos_work queue once we calc_latency while configuring the uart port.
    
    Flush and complete any pending qos jobs in work queue while suspending.
    
    Signed-off-by: Govindraj.R &lt;govindraj.raja@ti.com&gt;
    Acked-by: Greg Kroah-Hartman &lt;gregkh@suse.de&gt; (for drivers/tty changes)
    Signed-off-by: Kevin Hilman &lt;khilman@ti.com&gt;

|Patch Set 1:

Felipe,
It seems the dwc-&gt;mode should be in sync with the mode set in hw.
That is the intent.. 
dwc3_set_mdoe is called from debugfs and at that place dwc-&gt; mode is not updated like it is in dwc3_probe(). (maybe forgoten)

Tero,

Recently, it was deemed that i719 was applicable to all OMAP4/5, hence there isn't a check.
|Patch Set 6:

There is no road map after OMAP5, there isn't a practical need .
Your point is noted.
I will incorporate that later this week.
|Patch Set 6:

errata flags cannot be considered in this patch.. since they belong in the ehci driver related structure.
The next version of this patch will call the sar save or not from within the ehci driver context. That requires some decent amount of code change in the omap-sar.c file and separate sar_ram_layout will be created for usbhs. I have an idea how that needs to be done. This comment will be incorporated in that change.
I notice that in p-linux-omap-3.4. there is no account of OMAP3.
Your review comments are with good intention but I wanted to block out omap3 but there are not even any data structures for omap3 sar, but maybe I missed it ... hence did not bother.
If the next version of the patch works out .. the errata flags will be set and used and your comments addressed.

|Patch Set 1: Verified

|Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I understand the good intent of decreasing the code size etc, but I think this is super backdoor way that IMO can/should be avoided.
|Patch Set 1:

Patch Set 1:
&gt; I understand the good intent of decreasing the code size etc
Ruchika, BSS-section is really intended to decrease code size, but it's not what I've done. BSS section exists always, whether you want it or not -- it's how linker works (check arch/omap5/eboot.lds file). So I didn't provide it. I just cleared it with &quot;0&quot; in this patch. 
[Rk] Yes I understand.
Because it must be zeroed to compliance with ANSI C standard.
[Rk] Is there a requirement to support compilers that are non ANSI C (ISO C)  ?

&gt; but I think this is super backdoor way that IMO can/should be avoided.
Can you please explain, why do you think that clearing of BSS section is backdoor? How can you use it as backdoor?
[Rk] The compiler/linker should be zeroing it out and this should not be done at runtime. This may even increase the boot time to some extent.

|Have you tried giving a 50msec delay instead? May be a timing issue
|Yes. I understand that. But why is this being removed in the current patch? Is it related to the fix for set format? Was itcausing a functionality break/regression?
|Emilian: Why is mBufSize calculation removed?
|Increasing prev bufs causing frame drops &amp; AV Ts mismatch. Holding this patch till we root-cause  the actual issue.
|Sundar.. I think this checkk was introduced by one of the patches from emilian to fix some zoom issue.

Is this check causing any undesired effect?
|Yes keith. That is the intended final solution. We need to insert the logic in camerahal &amp; test.

This will be removed once it's implemented. This is a WA for the time being.
|I was seeing a weird crash with this. thought valid for omap3.

But yeah.. we can protect it with omap macro untill it's tested there..
|Keith. The -1 is required put the I-Frames at exact 30th position. FOr example if the IFrameinterval is set as 1. The I-Frames is inserted at exactly Frame-Rate position + 1. If we have a frame rate of 30, it will be inserted ar 31st position. By inserting -1, we put the I-Frames at exactly 30th position which is requested by the user.

We have used the same logic in Opencore previously
|Keith. It's upto the user to to choose where he wants to place the I-Frame. We are using -1 as per the suggestion from our codec team.
|Kalpesh.. Pls remove the StopPreview() &amp; StartPreview() from this patch. It's not related to this.

Needs to be root-caused why there is a hang without Stop &amp; Start. We will do more debugging before inserting this.
|Tyler.. Irrespective of when Ducati team provides a fix, we still need this as we cannot base video time stamps on System monotonic timer. This will give irresular spacing of TS.

When ducati team do provide a fix, this fix acts like further protection to other system latencies which might affect AV-Sync.
|Sundar.. This delta is a huge number ranging from 2 to 11 seconds! We've seen that the way ducati is interpolating the system time &amp; the way kernel does is different. We suspect that to be the issue. Ducati team is looking into this parallelly.
|Is mWantsNALFragments condition introduced to distinguish between Software &amp; Ducati codecs? I guess software codec uses this quirk. Can you pls write few comments on this?
|Is mIsEncoder flag not to be checked here again?
I'm worried abt record record use-case. Have you validated video-record use-case with this patch?
|Does Memcpy happen for software codecs?
|Dangling Pointer. CAn you set tmpbuffer to NULL?
|can you make it mrotationupdated?
|What is the memory part he's trying to address?
|Satya.. what is the the scenario described in the above lines? 
what is OOM?
|why do you need the rotationupdated flag when you are already checking for current angle &amp; last angle?
|Ricky.. I agree with you.. But i cannot comment on OMAP3 as i've not tested with this patch on OMAP3 platform. That's whythis patch is provided as OMAP4 specific only. 

If OMAP3 folks find similar issue on their platform, we can remove OMAP4 specific macro &amp; just include OMAP_ENHANCEMENT as you've suggested.
|Dan.. As explained in the description field of the patch, the AV-Sync issue here refers to lip-sync not achieved in recorded video. That is, if we record a video with a person talking, we will observe that the synchronization between Audio &amp; video is not perfect.

Since the issue is related to Android framework &amp; not OMAP specific, it is valid for OMAP3 as well. Keun o. Park from OMAP3 team has verified this patch on Zoom2.

Anyways as suggested by you, I will include couple of lines of comment to make clear about AV-Sync.
|That's rite. I will correct this :)
|I will correct the spelling mistakes.

We are not sure with what configuration Google has tested this code. They may or may not be seeing the issue depending on Audio &amp; Video parameters they are using. like higher Audio sampling rate, Audio buffer sizes, etc.
|Will correct it
|Why is this made false again? Do you expect the function to get called repetitively? In that case this flag shoul;d be set as static.
|1) Remove the CSR ID &amp; insert comments instead

2) The description of the patch says &quot;Skip Zero Size chunks in MP4 parser&quot;. But the actual skipping is happening below under OMAP_ENHANCEMENT macro. This code should be wrapped in OMAP_ENHANCEMENT macro OR the logic to skip the zero size chunks should be un-wrapped with OMAP_ENHANCEMENT. ELse it will cause the paser to enter infinite loop, as described in the below code.
|Does this mean we lock the orientation during record to LAndscape/Portrait always?
|Why can't this logic be handled at the cameraHAL level as it's done in OMAP4?
|Port type not set for h264type.
|The pFrame calculation is common for for MPEG4 &amp; H264. Only B-Frame is not valid for MPEG4
|This is not required. We need to update the nPframes using setconfig. Dont change the target frame rate for B-Frames. Just update the nPFrames according to new frame rate to match iFrameInterval
|Just realized GOLCD doesn't apply for DSI. Can be thought for GODIGITAL
|Srinivas.. Since Pipeline Attr is a shadow register, can 't we delay the GOLCD/GDIGITAL bit untill we set the proper BA0/BA1 on resume? This will avoid accessing of wrong Base address.
|Deva.. Why do we need the configuration of pipelines in save &amp; restore context?

As srinivas saying, these will be reconfigured anyway at resume.
|Why can't we have a condition like Width &gt;= 1080 &#124;&#124; Height &gt;= 1080?
This will be valid for both 1080p portrait &amp; landscape?

Have you verified with Camera Ducati team on what's the threshold above which you need sensor overclocking.

We need to overclock if either width/height crosses that threshold.
|Sathya.. Again my question would be what is the threshold resolution after which you need Overclocking? This needs to be found deterministically.

And any resolution that crosses the threshold needs to have overclocking.

For Example if 720p is the threshold, we need to overclock the sensor for any Resolution greater than 720p. i.ee if If width &gt; 1280 &amp;&amp; Ht &gt; 720. &#124;&#124; if width &gt; 720 &amp;&amp; Ht &gt; 1280 (In case of rotation)

|hardcoding.. avoid magic numbers.

0x60 is missed

|remove the tab after out_height

|This is a protection if external TE is used. I'm considering all four probability of TE_TIMEOUT &amp; FRAMEDONE_TIMEOUT unlocking the bus.

The issue in hand will get fixed, upon only checking bus status in taal_framedone_cb() function. 

Maybe i need to update the description field stressing this.
|I don't feel this is an workaround. The DSI driver is registering for both TE timeout as well as Framedone Timeout (250msec). Remember timeouts occur ONLY on error scenario.

It should also be noted that for a command mode panel, TE_TIMEOUT will eventually result in FRAMEDONE_TIMEOUT. 

The current code, releases the semaphore for both the timeouts one after the other which is causing the crash.

I'm just stop signalling at framedone timeout and use TE timeout for precise timeout signaling. [TE GPIO]

What needs to be thought is whether FRAMEDONE timeout can occur without TE_TIMEOUT (which is unlikely). This requires the logic to be amanded to use the semaphore count before releasing it.

But this patch is required to fix multiple signaling for the same timeouts (although appear to be different manifestations)
|Anyways i'm contemplating to improve this patch which can handle all the timeouts, without need to remove anything

buffet --&gt; correct this
|OK.. It works like this.. Both TUNA &amp; OMAP5 sEVM (LG4591) have the same resolution (720 x 1280). The video editor App picks up the layout files based on the dpi of the panel. 

Now here's the fix: TUNA although has the same resolution as the sEVM panel, the height is bigger than the sEVM. Due to this, the png files created to have the pause, ffw, rwd, play button is very much inline with TUNA panel.

Now since the video editor code is the same for both OMAP5 &amp; TUNA, the video editor is loading the same set of png files even for LG4591, causing the icons to appear bigger &amp; cover the preview area.

What i still don't know is that the icons (play/pause/rwd/ffw) for omap5sevm is getting picked from the mdpi (medium-dpi) whereas it's getting from xhdpi for TUNA. This is NOT the root-cause of the problem though. There are still offsets for OMAP5 that is taken care by this patch.

We cannot hardcode the icon files inside mdpi folder as this is chosen by the system. Now we searched through the net &amp; didn't find satisfying info on what exactly is the condition (apart from panel dpi) that determines icons size.

So we have created the icons on the same lines as google &amp; uploaded for omap5.

Pls let us know if you have a better fix for this?

|7 vsync is 7 * 16.66 = 116 msec rite?? why do we need 300 msec??
|Even the original patch did NOT forward the compositions to the DSSCOMP when num_ovls was equal to 0.
if(psDssData-&gt;num_ovls == 0 &#124;&#124; ui32NumMemInfos == 0)
{
                        return false;
}

This patch actually fakes the composition complete to the SGX by calling commandcompelete so that we don't crash. So this patch is actually getting over a crash instead of returning an error condition. This should be clearly indicated in the description field.

Don't you think, this is a HACK &amp; something that should have been handled by the HWC?
|Ya.. i agree.. This is what is missing in description field. I have no objection to content of the patch. But the description doesn't correctly explain what you are trying to do in this patch. 

Whatever given in the description was already handled before this patch &amp; this patch, along with that, does a error recovery by NOT sending the error, and instead faking the composition complete in error scenario so that there's NO SGX crash seen, due to missing compositions.
|Gus.. On OMAP5 we've tried using values ranging from 16666666 to 17544444. The issue is not seen only when physical VSYNC's of the panel made much more than than the referesh value used here in HWC. As of today, we are configuring the panel to get VSYNC's at 62 fps &amp; adjusted the porch values (used by DDK to deduce fps) to get the software value to 57 fps. This is what is used the hwc. With this, we are not seeing any frame drops for 60 fps videos, even when multiple layers are active.

But along with the above, we needed one more patch in AwesomePlayer.cpp to fix the jitter (rendering happening at non-periodic intervals).

We tried experimenting waitforvsync but didn't yield good results. Also we need HWC to be panel aware &amp; not straightforward in case of command mode panels which uses framedone's &amp; not vsync.
|how did you arrive with this number?

|Pls remove the tab.. you can check the font errors by running checkpatch script. FOr example, you have 0001.xx..yy..zz.patch &amp; you want to ensure it is free of font errors. 

1) Goto your kernel source in your terminal (kernel/omap) 
2) type ./scripts/checkpatch.pl &lt;patch name&gt;
3) you will get the errors &amp; warnings (if any)

|Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve


|Patch Set 3:

Keith : This use-case occurs when we do an AV-Record of 1080p. At the end of AV record, 2 thumbnails are generated(mini thumbnail at the top-right corner &amp; normal thumbnail for playback of video) along with Encoder node creation (H264 OR MPEG4 OR H263)&amp; Camera preview. 

This is a mega memory consuming use-case which requires trading between memory &amp; execution speed. Currently we have bluntly serialized the execution by introducing huge delays (Approx 2secs) between decoder &amp; encoder creations. This has a bad user-experience at the end of record.

This patch, utilizes the NPA mode supported by ducati to optimize memory. We already use this mode in encoders. It's now introduced for decoders as well. This greatly helps reduce the memory &amp; help improve performance of AV-record use-case.

|Patch Set 2:

Pankaj.. I initially tried using the offset between the start time of Audio &amp; video, as you suggested. This offset is updated in track header under 'elst' box of the 3gp parser.

But this offset is only about the start time of Audio &amp; video. It doesn't account for the time where video thread is blocked. It is this time which is causing the audio to record half a second early as compared to video.

After this patch i'm seeing the offset &lt; 100msec. Worst-case i tried recording a 5fps clip, which has an offset of 200 msec.

|Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Jean.. I don't have objection to the fix as it's only OMAP3 specific. We (OMAP4) have similar logic handled at the cameraHAL &amp; wanted to know if the same can be done for OMAP3 as well. This will avoid touching of SF code. Just wanted to know that. If the CameraHAL design cannot accomodate this, we can go ahead with the fix.

+1 since it's urgent &amp; need to go into the tree.
|Patch Set 2:

Keith.. In OMAP4 we have the reference count mechanism in CameraHAL which doesn't allow the buffer to be released untill it's returned by both Encoder &amp; Overlay (After display). We have 6 preview buffers in total, of which 3 buffers are passed to both encoder &amp; Overlay. We increment the reference count once it's sent to the encoder &amp; increment it again when sending to overlay.

WHen the buffer gets returned from encoder we decrement the refernce count &amp; wait untill the same buffer is returned from Overlay. Once encoder &amp; overlay return the buffer, the refernce count would have become zero &amp; we release the buffer to OMX Camera for filling. This way we avoid tearing.
All the details can be found in OMXCameraAdapter.cpp file in CameraHal folder. 

It's evident that it's a design level change if it's not implemented previously. That's why i wanted to know if it's been implemented at CameraHAL level or not. 

As far as the fix is concerned i don't have any problem with it since it's protected by OMAP3 macro.

|Patch Set 2:

Hi Tyler,

I had similar issues on OMAP4. All the details are provided in the below patch. In our case, Audio used to get recorded 500ms early.

http://review.omapzoom.org/#change,12123

It's a thredaing issue in GB, which seems to have been fixed in HC onwards. 

The above patch was reviewed by OMAP3 folks as well. If you see that Video is ahead of Audio, it's possible that the above patch could be causing issues. Try reverting the patch on your setup.

As far as this fix is concerned, i don't think it's a good idead to tweak the offset time although it's simple &amp; solves the problem :)

|Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Jagadeesh:

1) The S3D WB support design is not inline with original DSSCOMP design. For example, you have introduced composition mode for every composition. Did you have a design review with any of video team members before this? [like Lajos/Sunita/Saket]?? This has implication on non-S3D compositions as well. Why do we need to go for this approach, just to show S3D content? I mean did you evaluate any alternate Design approaches before freezing on this design? 

2) From code review, there are DSS specific functions like framedone irq handler, dispc enable functions which are not supposed to be present in DSSCOMP module. 

3) Since these design changes are tightly coupled with HWC changes, we need to have a design review with Graphics team as well. Pls involve Tony L in the HWC design &amp; code review.
|Patch Set 8: Fails; I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(18 inline comments)

I have concerns on the amount of change this patch is bringing in DSSCOMP in one go. Pls consider following suggestions:

1) Add a new s3d.c file &amp; move all the s3d specific code inside that file. Pls remove low level codes from DSSCOMP &amp; shift it to DSS driver

2) Pls arrange the code in more modular way, breaking the codes into smaller functions &amp; only calling the functions from DSSCOMP with proper comments so that everyone understand what the code actually doing. I tried hard to understand full code, but failed ;)

3) Pls follow the coding standards in the re-work:
Coding Standards:

Kernel:  Kernel Coding Standards
http://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/CodingStyle

AFS:  Code Style Guidelines for Contributors
http://source.android.com/source/code-style.html

4) All the major Video use-cases must be validated before marking it verified Ex: Normal Playback, S3D Playback, Camcorder, Video Editor, Web-Browsing, HDMI Docking &amp; Cloning.

|Patch Set 3:

Hi.. (-1 for tracking)

1) Can you give the numbers on what is the current Functional clock generated by DSI PLL that is fed to DISPC?? 

2) What is the use-case where DSI PLL generated functional clock is not sufficient for the DISPC, that you have to use PRCM clock?

3) Even if the clock is not sufficient, why can't you increase the functional clock speed from the DSI PLL, by decreasing the dividers? (DSI PLL has two clocks, one fed to DSI PE &amp; the Other to DISPC &amp; both are independent) Why do you need to goto PRCM clock?

4) Have you measured the power numbers on switching to PRCM clock from DSI PLL?
|Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this


|Patch Set 3:

Thanks for clarifying. If the functioanl clock was not enough, how is the current design working for all resolutions?

Is this a customer specific issue? I don't remember seeing this issue while suspend resume.
|Patch Set 3:

Lajos. DSI PLL has two outputs which are independent. One of the output is controlled by the M4 divider, which goes as the DSI functional clock. It's calculated by DPHY/(M4+1).

The other output is controlled by the M5 factor is fed to the DISPC. i.e.. DPHY/(M5+1). 

My question was, if the clock is not enough for driving the HDMI, why can't we increase it in the DSI PLL? WHat is the rational behind moving to PRCM? I don't agree to the theory of DSI PLL to be used ONLY when DSI is on. If that were the case, there wouldn't be having option to choose DISPC functional clock.

I remember that PRCM clcok adds to the power numbers than using the internal PLL. That's why i asked to measure the power numbers when switching to PRCM.

Although i'm ok with the functionality of the patch, i still feel there is a room for optimizations.

As far as your question is concerned, we cannot change the dividers run-time. We have to unlock the PLL &amp; Lack-back with the new values. The factor is determoned by the formula given above. If the current DSI PLL clock is 138 MHz, we can increase it to 148.5 &amp; feed the same to DISPC as well.
|Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

|Patch Set 1:

Dan data_lock is the spinlock dedicated to protect the DSS data transitions in the cache.

It was a coding mistake on my part to have included the spin_lock at the beginning of the mgr-&gt;blank() function, without considering the fact that ovs-&gt;disable() also uses the same spinlock inside.

Once ovl_disable() is complete, we should again use the same spin_lock to protect further dss_data transition.

|Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, approved


|Patch Set 1: Do not submit


|Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve


|Patch Set 1:

Archit.. By refresh rate, i mean FPS &amp; not panel refresh rate. Thta's why i'm referring &quot;Frame&quot; refresh rate.

As you said the pixelclock is used by the clients to determine the refresh rate, which is of PRIME importance in Android (Although not set in hwardware which is fixed). In Android we have multiple layers from surface flinger preparing &amp; setting their compositions in separate threads. They don't rely on refresh rate or underlying hardware. They post Asynchronously based on user inputs.

It's this refresh rate which holds all the layers together &amp; ensures we don't post anything more than the refresh rate of the panel (60 Hz). 

That's the reason we were seeing frame drops when multiple layers were active as the refresh rate was set to 64 fps (I don't know why it was set to 64 in the first place!) &amp; for a 60 fps clip, the maximum wait time for layer update was reduced considerably, resulting in frame drop.

The formula used to calculate the RefreshRate is standard (Width + Porch) * (Height + Porch) * Pixel clock.

The pixelclock here is the pico2khz pixel clock &amp; not the Mhz one.
|Patch Set 1:

Archit.. Your calclateion is correct. Just that it needs to e divided by 1000 &amp; consider rounding off factor in two places:

1) SGX where the base fps is calculated
2) HWC where RefreshRate is deduced.

|Patch Set 5:

The question is not about opening another DRT to track regression. It's about avoiding it as much as possible. We have to ensure the current patch induces no more regression. I'm stressing this as i've seen regression in Gallery before which led to un-necessary escalations.

All i'm asking is to do more stress testing (like all the gallery options working) with the patch to ensure it doesn't impact any of the existing gallery functionality. I'm not asking to run robustness.

|Patch Set 2: (4 inline comments)

The next_eventUS considers only the earliness &amp; frame rendering case. It doesn't handle case where the frame is late &amp; getting dropped. Consider the case when you post a event for a frame after it gets rendered &amp; the next frame comes late for rendering &amp; gets dropped. What happens to the next_eventUS?

OR consider when we do a seek, which can cause:

1) dropping several frames due to multiple layer synchronization in surface flinger. 

2) Proper sync where the mediatime is updated.

What happens to next_eventUS??

I feel, printing the lateness alone is enough to track the jitter. For printing the lateness time, we can just use two prints, before &amp; after the release &amp; track it logcat -v by using print time option

|Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve


|The omap_pm_set_min_bus_tput should not be called directly. It should be populated to a pdata ptr and called through it. 

No magic number please.

It is little misleading because ios-&gt;clock is essentially card frequency. 
High speed SD is either 25MHz or 50MHz.
High Speed MMC is 52Mhz or 26MHz.
Standard MMC is 20Mhz.
It seems this works only because you are saving the frequency at which OMAP is driving below. Was this done to avoid setting up the constraints multiple times?
|This does not take care of the scenario where power_saving is not enabled. Going fwd there is always a chance that MMC5 on which WIFI is connected might disable power_saving.
|Setup the default dma_type to SDMA_XFER. Otherwise if this condition fails the dma_type will be zero and PIO is not supported yet.

|Patch Set 1: Verified

|Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)


|Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

1. This patch fails to handle the case where power_saving is disabled. In this case during bootup the constraint would get set in set_ios and will never get released.

2. The changes done to the set_ios function would fail to set the constraint during boot time if 4-bit/8-bit mode is disabled. The effect of this is not seen only because the constraint is again set in omap_hsmmc_enable.

3. The changes made to omap_hsmmc_disable function has a failure case. If the card is removed from the slot the system is left with a constraint.This is because the set_ios drops the frequency and the patch still checks for 24Mhz before releasing the constraint.
|Patch Set 3: Verified

Approved.
|Patch Set 1: Verified

Approved.
|Patch Set 2:

The omap_hsmmc_request calls the omap_hsmmc_start_command fn. But for MMC5 the polling_enabled is set to 1 before start_command is called.So irq will be in disabled state because the probe fn disables irq the first time.
|Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

|Patch Set 1:

Replacing msleep with mdelay would increase the boot time.
The change to board file to remove the always_on is coupled with the msleep because this is needed for pbias to ramp up.
Otherwise the change in board file will break SD card detection.
|Uploaded patch set 2.

|All mutex intializations are done before EXIT. 
To destroy mutexes in case of error, (OMX_ErrorNone != eError) check is sufficient. No extra variable (bMutexInit) is required.
|when dlopen() fails it sets some non-zero value as the error message.
so checking (error = dlerror()) != NULL) is not required.
|when dlopen() fails it sets some non-zero value as the error message.
so checking (error = dlerror()) != NULL) is not required.
|if (pHandle == NULL pComponentPrivate == NULL)
*pState = OMX_StateLoaded;

Is this not required ?
|If dlsym() fails, error will be returned from dlsym() fail, not required to check for NULL. If NULL is added then if(eError != OMX_ErrorNone) code block has to be moved inside the NULL check loop
|Better to replace G722D_OMX_MALLOC_SIZE(pTemp-&gt;pBuffer) with OMX_MALLOC_SIZE_DSPALIGN()
|If dlsym() fails, error will be returned from dlsym() fail, not required to check for NULL. If NULL is added then if(eError != OMX_ErrorNone) code block has to be moved inside the NULL check loop
|first component level removal of GOTOs is done.
once all the components are done with removal of &quot;goto EXIT&quot; changes, then macro level removal of EXIT (MALLOC and other macros where EXIT is used) has to be done.

When macro level changes(removing EXIT from macros) are done, then there is a chance that allocated pointer may be NULL if the memory allocation fails. For that reason NULL check is added after all MALLOCs.

|There is a compile warning associated with this.
dlerror() return value is const char * as per dlerror() definition given below,
const char *dlerror(void);
In order to fix the warning const is prefixed.
|nParam is of type OMX_U32 (unsigned int), but comparison is made with signed value.
In order to fix the compile warning &quot;signed, unsigned comparision&quot;, typecasting is done.

Hi Manuel,

Can we add this change also ?
Increment the variables before writing data to pipe in  EmptyThisBuffer() and FillThisBuffer()

pComponentPrivate-&gt;nUnhandledFillThisBuffers++;
pComponentPrivate-&gt;nFillThisBufferCount++;

nRet = write (pComponentPrivate-&gt;dataPipe[1], &amp;pBuffer, sizeof (OMX_BUFFERHEADERTYPE*));
if (nRet == -1) {
    pComponentPrivate-&gt;nUnhandledFillThisBuffers--;
    pComponentPrivate-&gt;nFillThisBufferCount--;
    MP3D_OMX_ERROR_EXIT(eError,OMX_ErrorHardware,&quot;write    failed: OMX_ErrorHardware&quot;);
}

Regards,
Suneetha

|Uploaded patch set 3.
|Patch Set 3: Verified

Added frame mode support for TI AAC component only by checking for component name.

This patch should be integrated once we migrate to SN 3.16, since it has dependency on SN's multi-framemode support. Multi-framemode support for AAC component will be available as part of SN3.16 release.
|Patch Set 3:

Setting framemode for ADTS streams helps error streams 
(ADIF/RAW streams will remain same) to work better. 

When erroneous data is given to Codec, codec is not able to recover from errors as stream mode doesn't guarantee frame boundary and Codec is not recovering from errors leading to playback hang. 

As opencore/stagefright guarantees data to be on frame boundary for ADTS streams, so we are setting framemode for ADTS streams, but each buffer can contain multiple frames (variable in number in Stagefright). 

SN's previous implementation of framemode expects single frame per buffer, but giving only one frame buffer might lead to performance issues. So for this SN has come up with multi-frame mode support. When errors are detected Codec outputs zero pcm, flushes the current buffer and proceeds with next buffer as data is on frame boundary. This way when errors are detected maximum of a buffer data (max. of number of frames in that buffer) can be lost and can decode the other data successfully.

As SN is supporting multi-framemode it is not required to change parser to send single frame per buffer.

I think this works better for all ADTS streams.
|Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve


|Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Good finding Manual.

May be it is good to have FrameWork to choose between framemode or multi-framemode configuration for OMX.

multi-framemode
OMX.TI.index.config.AacDecMultiFrameModeInfo
OMX_IndexCustomAacDecMultiFrameModeConfig

|Uploaded patch set 2.
|Patch Set 2:

|Uploaded patch set 3.
|Patch Set 3:

media_profiles is rebased properly.

480p, 720p and 1280p camcorder profiles were removed intentionally because they are not supported by webcams.  Having 480p and 1280p (aspect 16:9) is not harmful but 720p profile is a different case.  Video recorder would try to use it (without consulting with hardware beforehands!) and would crash as this mode is not supported by 4:3 webcams.  In the absence of this profile Recorder would fall back to &quot;high&quot; profile.

On the other hand &quot;high&quot; and &quot;low&quot; capture profiles are mandatory and are set to the modes supported by common webcams.
|Uploaded patch set 4.

|Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Mike, support for USB video class devices (webcams) is not enabled by default
|The intent seems to be that the clock is enabled in case hdmi is used (but I don't know the history of why it was added in the first place).  This was ported from the p-android-2.6.32 code, and I left it in so as to potentially not break functionality.
|The gpio is (re)configured in case it was changed outside the control of the driver (but very unlikely).  For example the user reconfigures it through sysfs.  This was in the p-android-2.6.32 code, but since it's not expensive to reconfigure a gpio, I left it in.
|Should be 0x0 rather than NULL; omap_uart_state.padconf is a u16 offset, and not a pointer.
|Patch Set 2:

There were too many problems too address in this change.  This change will be abandoned, and replaced with changes 13199 to 13206.
|Patch Set 1:

I have verified that the OMAP3 PER domain goes off without this patch.  McBSP[2..4] are in PER and used for audio on the OMAP3.

The intent seems to be that McBSP clocks are enabled/disabled as needed through omap_mcbsp_request() and omap_mcbsp_free().  The OMAP sound driver does this in omap_mcbsp_dai_startup() and omap_mcbsp_dai_shutdown() when a PCM device is opened/closed.  Since the McBSP suspend callback is missing (added by the patch), the implication is that PER will not enter OFF state if an ALSA PCM device is opened.  This may be the intended effect -- allowing PER to go off by disabling all McBSP clocks on suspend may have unintended consequences if audio is in use.

As this patch affects OMAP4, and PER can enter OFF state (at least on OMAP3) without it, I don't think this patch is necessary.
|Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hi Francois.  Agreed on the padconf being board specific and does not belong in mux34xx.c.  However, I don't think it belongs in sounds/soc/omap/zoom2.c either.  The convention seems to be that the padconf setup is done in arch/arm/mach-omap2/ or arch/arm/plat-omap/.  I've opted to put the mcbsp mux setup in arch/arm/mach-omap2/board-zoom2-asoc.c.

|Patch Set 1: Verified

Tested with headset and bluetooth (SCO mode).
Testing steps were roughly (BT example) as follows.

(setup audio routing)
/system/bin/alsa_amixer -D hw:0 'McBSP3 Sidetone' on
/system/bin/alsa_amixer -D hw:0 'McBSP3 Sidetone Channel 0' 8192
/system/bin/alsa_amixer -D hw:0 'McBSP3 Sidetone Channel 1' 8192
echo 32767 &gt;/sys/devices/platform/omap-mcbsp.2/st_taps

# Do not record loop audio via CPU
arecord -D plughw:0,2 -f S16_LE -r 16000 &gt; /dev/null &#124; aplay -D plughw:0, -f S16_LE -r 16000 /dev/zero

|Patch Set 1:

Hi Chris,
This fix is for OMAPS00243523.
|Patch Set 1: Verified


|Patch Set 1: No score; I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Agreed, further investigation revealed that this is a fix for an invalid test case, per OMAPS00215188.
|Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Fix is for an invalid test case and prevents full duplex hands free operation.
|Done
|Done
|Dan, The exact issue is stated below:

DISPC programming happens on the FCLK (LCD_EN bit written in slaveport).
Unsynchronized LCD_EN bit triggers the Timing Generator FSM running on LCD_CLK. Trigger event generation assumes a single cycle behavior considering LCD_EN to be stable.
In OMAP4x the LCD_CLK gating is enabled using the synchronized version of LCD_EN signal which ensures that by the time regStartFSM and regLcdEnPclk receive the LCD_CLK the LCD_EN is stable.
In OMAP5430 ES1.0 the clock gating has an issue and thereby the LCD_CLK is free running.

Already shared the ppt. with you, along with the proposed WA.
|Done
|Done
|Done
|Making a check while calling this function itself. Called only in VIDEO mode. 
In HDMI case, this will never be called, as it is for dsi, hence no check required for that.
|Checked with HW team, it is applicable for 5432 also, hence we can keep the check as it is.
|Both PCD and dsi_fclk will never be zero. This has already been taken care in dispc.
|During wakeup, the value was set to 64Hz due to no specific reason.
We don't support clips with higher fps than 60, hence resetting the value to 60Hz

Dan, Sreenidhi,
It is not possible to put only the required value in the xml file. The system takes entire xml(if present) file from device/ti/omap5sevm and overrides the one from packages/apps folder. 

If we need to change even a single value, we need to put the entire xml file. 
Same can be seen at : https://android.dal.design.ti.com/#change,5644,patchset=2

|Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

This was taken care in the K3.0 kernel using pm_runtime_put_autosuspend which will call the otg_suspend in the omap2430_runtime_suspend function. The charger detection patch is put some extra clock enable/disable in the phy_power function which is creating a problem.

The proper fix should be enable/disable the clocks in the charger_detection function and keep the phy_power as original function. This will solve the hot unplug issue.
|Patch Set 5: (3 inline comments)

|Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I don't think this has to be fixed this way. Thare is already a function in which it is taken care of cold boot scenario.
You can do the following to fix the cold boot issue.

in omap2430_musb_enable() enable the UTMI mode.
By default it is in ULPI mode so there should not be any issue with charger detection.
|Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Hema/Moiz,

Can you please clearly explain how this patch is helping? the phy_shutdown call is already done before the set_suspend() where phy clocks are cut. Also, logically we are just telling musb that there is a session end by writing to the control reg, how does phy clocks being on or not affect this?

otg_shutdown function will not disable the phy clocks.  
otg_set_suspend(musb-&gt;xceiv, 1) is the one which will disable the phy clocks.
In the current code we are calling otg_set_suspend(musb-&gt;xceiv, 1) which is disabling the clocks before the SESSION END bit in the control module is set which would miss the disconnect interrupt of MUSB.

The flow should be as below:
1. in the disconnect(VBUS_NONE) event handler there is runtime auto suspend function called. 
2. Otg_set_suspend function is called to diable the phy clocks before changing the interface select to UTMI 2. call otg_set_suspend function to enable the phy clock back.
3. otg_shutdown is called to set the SESSIONEND bit of control module which will enable the musb to generate the DISCONNECT interrupt.
4. after the timeout the pm_runtime_put_sync will be called to disable the musb and disable the usb phy clocks and shutdown the phy.

With this sequence every thing should work fine without any issues. Please let me know if you need more clarifications.

 + .io_pg_offst    = ((0xfa400000) &gt;&gt; 18) &amp; 0xfffc,

|Patch Set 1: Verified


|Patch Set 2: Verified

Verified
|The C_states defined arei n 1P configuration where CPU1 is OFF. So CPU0 will be in WFI and MPU INA.

As already said by Mike in the case of 2P, CPUx WFI will be hit in omap4_enter_idle function
|Yes when we are in SMP no power management. The 2 CPUs can only do WFI.
This is the case currently in the code even without this patch.
|The C_states thresholds are calculated based on our measurements done on L24.11 kernel and estimations done by architecture team.
THese thresholds values are not optimized as our latencies are not optimized yet.
For this reason, what we need is that to have the C-states implemented on Android. Then a New pass of measurements will be done in order to refine these thresholds on Android products.

All the latencies are very high: if we just take the ramp up/down of vdd_mpu it is set to 1.8ms currently so just by optimizing this value we'll reduce the latency of ~1.5 ms... more optimization should also be done in order to reduce these latencies.

What I propose is to implement these C-states, we can reduce thresholds if you want in order to be able to enter them. New measurements will be done on Android and we'll fine tune these values.
|For IVA the prescal should be equal to 1 and the ramp should be equal to B so the register value should be 0x010B010B and not 0x001B001B. The code should be:
voltage_write_reg(OMAP4_PRM_VOLTSETUP_IVA_RET_SLEEP_OFFSET,
(0x1 &lt;&lt; OMAP4430_RAMP_DOWN_PRESCAL_SHIFT) &#124;
(0x1 &lt;&lt; OMAP4430_RAMP_UP_PRESCAL_SHIFT) &#124;
(0xB &lt;&lt; OMAP4430_RAMP_DOWN_COUNT_SHIFT) &#124;
(0xB &lt;&lt; OMAP4430_RAMP_UP_COUNT_SHIFT));
|let's put back this function omap_hsi_resume_idle(); here.
Modem team will release another patch to move it
|let's put back the function omap_hsi_resume_idle() in omap4_enter_sleep.
Modem team will release another patch to move it
|the core_logic_state should be changed to PWRDM_POWER_OFF instead of RET for CORE In OSWR
|One more thing the comment needs to be updated MPU CSWR + CORE OSWR
|shouldn't we do the same for OMAP5 register 
 __raw_writel(voltctrl, OMAP5430_PRM_VOLTCTRL);  you are just writing the OMAP4 register?
|same comment here
|same comment here
Maybe for this reason you need the hacks to make it work on OMAP5
|Why using pwrdm_post_transition it should be pwrdm_pre_transition?

We already clear the prev powerst in the functions pre/post so no need to call the clear function before the pre/post anymore
|Why not calling the pwrdm_pre_transition function for the core_pd as well?
|please fix the comment /* replace by */ to avoid warnings during build
|Please move it to just after the call of the function omap_enter_low_power() to be coherent with what has been done on CORE
|we need to cut the clocks of the thermal even when CORE is going into INA.
|move the spin lock to cover the entire code, just before the wake_low =
|move the spin unlock to cover the entire code, to the end of the function
|I would prefer if you move it inside _omap5_gpio_apply_wa 
call it at the end when the gpio-&gt;bank.id==7
|I would prefer that you move it inside _omap5_gpio_remove_wa call it at the beginning when the gpio-&gt;bank.id ==0

in this way it is inside the WA function, it is cleaner
|Patch Set 1: Verified

(2 inline comments)

We need to implement the different C-states in order to be able to do our real measurments for fine-tuning the thresholds
|Patch Set 1:

Regaring the C1 threshold which is 150 us, I porpose to put it to a low value as well as the latencies in order to enter C1 in the use cases where estimated idle time &lt;150us.
If idle time &lt;93 us we'll not hit the targeted power state and if not we'll get a gain.

It was the case on OMAP3630 and this is what has been done

It is the C5 (C12) in our analysis

Jonathan,
Once we are in idle (the idle task is executed), this_cpu_load will return 0. Once you have activities, it will return values &gt; 0 which correspond to a weight of each process running and waiting in the queue

|Patch Set 2:

the MPU next power state is set at the beginning of the idle path in the function omap5_enter_idle
	if (atomic_read(&amp;cx-&gt;mpu_state_vote) == num_online_cpus()) {
		omap_set_pwrdm_state(mpu_pd, cx-&gt;mpu_state);
		omap_set_pwrdm_state(core_pd, cx-&gt;core_state);
	}

In the function omap_dec_mpu_core_pwrdm_usecount to disable SR you check the next power state of the MPU so the targeted power state that you have set in omap5_enter_idle as shown above. It is independent of the CPU states.

For the MPU to hit (in HW) the targeted power state you need to have your CPUs hitting the targeted power state.

But you disable you SR based on what you have programmed your MPU next power state( the targeted power state), you can never know from your SW if the MPU is really going to hit (HW level) the targeted power state.

So it should be fine with this patch, I have also put a trace in omap_sr_disable and it is being called

|Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

See 12310 for changes.
|Are you changing the poll rate to be every 0.5s from 5s?  I guess you can also update the comment to say &quot;milliseconds&quot;, if that is correct.
|Patch Set 1:

In hdmi.c, the request_irq() function should keep &amp;hdmi as the argument.  Instead, the free_irq() function should be changed (argument &amp;hdmi instead of 0) to match.  Otherwise, there is a dependency on omapdss.def_disp=hdmi in the bootargs, and we get a kernel panic if we don't set HDMI as the default display.
|Patch Set 1:

I believe that there is still a dependency issue with USB_ANDROID in this patch.  With the default configuration, USB peripheral works OK.  However, if we first make the USB to Host, then back to Peripheral, the USB Peripheral stops working.  It seems that USB_ANDROID is missing in this second case.
|Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Can we please get this reviewed and merged into the L27 tree?  We have been chasing a frequent kernel crash on loading the Android FS that was resolved by this patch.
